Otherwise they will be setting us up to fail.â€œWe have all been working very hard to craft alternative compromises and the government, frankly, hasnâ€™t a clue where the potential for consensus lies because it hasnâ€™t engaged properly.â€Then there is the question of the process by which&nbspMPs&nbspwould actually vote.One system would see the Commons ide on a series of yesno votes on specific proposals in the usual way.&nbspNorway-style Brexit may not be right for UK, says Icelandic PMWho is left to stop Theresa May from leading us to a no-deal Brexit?Seven Labour frontbenchers set to join Put it to the People march This is likely to appeal to Downing Street because, if all the alternatives were voted down, Ms May could insist her deal was the only viable outcome. The danger, though, is that no option receives a majority.&nbspIn a bid to avoid this â€œlast man standingâ€ scenario, an alternative devised by Sir Oliver would involve indicative votes&nbspusing a paper ballot, adapting the â€œdeferred isionsâ€ method&nbspused to hold some Commons votes.&nbspThis would allow MPs to rank Brexit outcomes in order of preferences, rather than simply voting yes or no to each one.&nbspAnother proposal&nbspwould see various rounds of voting held, with the least popular option being discarded at each stage.If&nbspindicative votes are to uncover the basis for a possible consensus in parliament, MPs would need to be free to vote with their conscience&nbsprather than whipped by their parties.Brexit minister Kwasi Kwarteng appeared to confirm this on Friday, telling the Commons: â€œIf the house is being asked to decide a way forward, it would be surprising if those votes were not free votes.â€If Ms Mayâ€™s deal is rejected once again, it is likely&nbspthat parliament will&nbspbe given its first formal opportunity to vote on what type of Brexit it wants â€“&nbspjust days before Britain was supposed to be leaving the EU.With ongoing doubts over whether any option would command a Commons majority, though, it is far from clear whether indicative votes&nbspwill provide the route out of the crisis that supporters hope they will.&nbspGot an unanswered question about Brexit? Brexiteers will undoubtedly want a credible Leave option, possibly no deal, while pro-EU campaigners will demand&nbspthe chance to stay in the EU on the ballot.I haven't marched for 50 years â€“ but I will for a Final Say on BrexitStudent leaders sign letter urging May to hold Final Say referendum Celebrities fund transport to Brexit protest for new EU referendumHereâ€™s how Theresa May can get around Bercowâ€™s dramatic Brexit rulingThe people will have a Final Say on Brexit. She is also running out of options to resolve the Brexit crisis.One scenario could see Ms May offer a second referendum to MPs in exchange for supporting her Brexit deal. Labour MPs Phil Wilson and Peter Kyle have worked up an amendment for a â€œconfirmatory voteâ€, where approval of the prime ministerâ€™s deal in the Commons would be conditional on throwing the question to the public.The Kyle-Wilson plan, as it is known, was drawn up in consultation with Jeremy Corbynâ€™s frontbench, suggesting it could secure that all-important Labour support in the Commons.It&nbspmight&nbspovercome speaker John Bercowâ€™s ruling that the prime minister cannot bring back her deal without â€œsubstantial changesâ€. Thai voters went to the polls on Sunday in a long-delayed election following a 2014 coup, a race that pits a military junta chief seeking to retain power against a democratic front led by the populist party he ousted.Turnout was expected to be high among the 51.4 million Thais eligible to vote for the 500-seat House of Representatives, which will choose the next government along with a Senate that is appointed entirely by the ruling junta.Thailand has been under direct military rule since then-army chief Prayuth Chan-ocha overthrew an elected government linked to exiled former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, who himself was thrown out by the army in 2006.Critics have said a new, junta-written electoral system gives a built-in advantage to pro-military parties and appears designed to prevent the Thaksin-linked Pheu Thai Party from returning to power.Pro-Thaksin parties have won every election since 2001, but the past 15 years have seen crippling street protests that destabilised the government and hamstrung business.Created with Sketch. I want to see love and unity. Everybody has one vote, one voice. Everybody wants democracy.The anti-Thaksin Yellow Shirts, mostly middle class and urban royalists who accuse his parties of corruption, have repeatedly taken to the streets, prompting the military to launch two coups in a decade.Thaksin's supporters, known as the Red Shirts, also occupied much of Bangkok's main business and shopping districts for months in 2010 after a court dissolved a pro-Thaksin government, again paralysing commerce until a crackdown that left at least 90 people dead and saw landmark buildings burned.While the election results are due to be announced within a few hours of polls closing at 5pm (10am&nbspGMT), the make-up of the next government may not be clear for weeks, since no one party is likely to have enough seats for an outright win.The country's king made an unexpected and cryptic statement hours before the vote, recalling a comment made by his late father in 1969 on the need to put good people in power and to prevent bad people from ... creating chaos.Although he did not refer to any of the sides in the race, there was speculation on social media that it was a coded reference to the country's political factions - broadly the middle class and urban establishment, who identify with the monarchy and the military, and their pro-Thaksin opponents.The king's intervention was a departure from the approach of his father, who in his latter years usually kept a distance between the monarchy and politics.It followed a startling turn of events last month when a party allied to Pheu Thai nominated Princess Ubolratana, the king's sister, as its prime ministerial candidate. It was then disqualified by a court after the king said it was inappropriate for members of the royal family to enter politics.Thai voters prepare for return of democracy despite 'rigged' systemKatie Price fails to attend court and heads off to Thailand insteadAustralians welcome refugee footballer after Thailand sets him freeWhat happened last month ... and then the announcement last night shows that, in contrast to the former reign, that the monarchy is actively interested in monitoring what's going on and it feels that it has some stake in the future direction of the country, said David Streckfuss, a Thailand-based independent scholar.The junta-written electoral rules ensure the military will continue to have a say in the next government, even if Mr&nbspChan-ocha does not stay on as prime minister.Pro-Thaksin parties are expected to win the largest number of seats in the House of Representatives. However, the new system appears designed to prevent it from forming a government because it includes the junta-appointed 250-seat Senate in the vote for prime minister.The provision means Mr&nbspChan-ocha's Palang Pracharat Party and allies have to win only 126 seats in the House, while Pheu Thai and its potential democratic front partners would need 376.Among the potential Pheu Thai allies is the new Future Forward Party, led by 40-year-old billionaire Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, whose criticism of the junta has been scathing and faces charges under the Computer Crimes Act for a critical Facebook speech. story: But Chancellor Philip Hammond has announced a further increase for some workers from .The National Living Wage is the amount of money all employees aged over  are legally entitled to.It used to be known as the National Minimum Wage, but it was re-branded in .The National Living Wage increased fromÂ Â£. to Â£.Â for those aged  and over.The  pence-an-hour rise was introduced on Sunday April , .From April , the National Living Wage will increase by  pence-an-hour to Â£..The compulsory National Living Wage was introduced in .The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.In Budget , Chancellor Hammond announced that lowest-paid workers will get another pay rise from next year to a minimum of Â£. per hour.Its a five per cent hike, which will come into force from April, and will benefit around .million workers.Mr Hammond said: From April [the National Living Wage] will rise again, handing a full-time worker a Â£ annual pay increase.Hammond is aiming to get the wage to Â£ by .It is dferent to the real living wage which is voluntary and not fixed by the government.The National Minimum Wage is the amount workers aged under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.However, the amount dfers depending on age and whether the worker is on an apprenticeship scheme.From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage is:From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage will be:The national limits are legally binding.Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

title: worlds craziest houses
story: But some homeowners have gone all out with their property - here we have pulled together ten of the most outrageous houses from all over the world.Dubbed the Heliodome, this house in France has been described as the â€œultimate solar architectureâ€.Its eye-catching design - constructed by a cabinet maker - is not just for a unique look but to capture the maximum amount of solar rays as possible.It provides free heating in the winter and cools down the house in the summer.But although it is an eco-friendly way of producing heat, many locals have complained about itâ€™s look saying it doesnâ€™t fit in with the French countryside.The giant seashell house is a joy to look at - with dozens of coloured mosaics that light up the indoors living space.The multicoloured house is in Mexico City and was built in .It is full of plants and natural light after being carefully designed but has all the features to make it a modern home.Despite its unusual shape it was designed to fit in with the natural surrounding and make the occupants feel like they were immersed in the wilderness.This WC-shaped house is made from steel, white concrete and glass, with a suggestive opening in the roof.It is in Seoul, South Korea, and continues the bathroom theme as it is full of toilets.The toilet house was built by Sim Jae-duck, chairman of the organising committee of the Inaugural General Assembly of the World Toilet Association.It is called â€œHaewoojaeâ€ which means â€œa place of sanctuary where one can solve oneâ€™s worriesâ€ in Korean.The upside down house is in Affoldern, Germany, and took only six weeks to build.It cost about â‚¬, and has an interior which is very disorientating to visitors.It was build in the village near the Edersee Lake in , and comes complete with bedrooms, a kitchen and bathroom.Every item, including crockery, a bath, knives and a toilet, is glued to the ceiling.Star Trek fans can live in a replica of the Voyager, complete with out of this world lighting and decor.The studio flat in Hinckley, Leicestershire, has been lovingly decked out with the main commands control.No detail has been overlooked in the m flat in the Midlands.It went on sale in  for Â£,.The Keret House in Warsaw, Poland, was the worldâ€™s narrowest house when it was built in .The tiny structure is squeezed in between two other buildings and has been described as more of an art installation.Apparently not as claustrophobic as it looks at cms at its widest point, a long ladder takes the occupant up through ious rooms, which look more like shelves.It was planned to be a temporary home for travelling writers.This snappy home is the work of an artist who died two months before it was completed.The crocodile house in the middle of Abidjan, Ivory Coast, is completely hollow.It was completed in  and is now lived in by Thierry Atta, who helped to build it.With windows and a bedroom the unique home is completely liveable and is a popular meeting place for many people in the neighbourhood.This lonely house was built in the middle of a river in .It is perched on a small rock near the Serbian town of Bajina Basta.It was built by a group of young men who thought the rock would be the best place for a tiny shelter, after they needed to rest while out swimming.The man who lives there today was part of the group and has seen off floods and high winds in his little home.One of the strangest homes in the world is one shaped like a giant glittering grand piano and a violin.It is in Huainan, China, and was built in .It features a glass violin propped up against the huge piano, which is the entrance to the house.The piano has a roof terrace beneath a canopy shaped like itâ€™s open top.

title: take what we can on brexit and scarper
story: This is according to the World Happiness Report.While the rest of the world is sinking into psychological depression, weâ€™re much more upbeat.Some of the British Press reporting this have used those dread words: â€œDespite Brexitâ€‰.â€‰.â€‰.â€‰â€It wouldnâ€™t occur to them that it might be BECAUSE of Brexit.I suspect for  per cent of us thatâ€™s pretty much the case. Maybe to keep up levels of national happiness we should leave horrible, authoritarian bureaucracies every year. Just to put a grin on our faces. I mean, the French donâ€™t seem very happy, do they But hereâ€™s the bad news. Theresa May is still Prime Minister and weâ€™re currently heading for a Brexit which would be a travesty of the one we voted for in . If we get Brexit at all.Some of the Brexiteers in Parliament think we might still be able to escape the EU with a No Deal, on World Trade Organisation terms. I think they are deluding themselves.Parliament, which is two to one in favour of NOT leaving the EU, simply will not let it happen.And the EU, desperate to retain its market for goods in the UK, will make sure it doesnâ€™t happen, too.Our Brexiteers are right that Theresa Mayâ€™s deal is awful. Butthey get a chance to vote on it again, they should hold their noses and vote in favour.Because I reckon itâ€™s that or nothing. We will have a delay, the EU may insist we hold a second referendum as a condition of that delay.And trust me, the second referendum will be rigged in favour of remaining in the EU. It will not be a straightforward in or out option. There will be three options, to split the Leave vote down the middle.In this fight to leave the EU, the British people have had everything against them. The EU, obvs. But also the House of Commons and the puffed-up, ludicrous, pro-Remain speaker John Bercow. And the House of Lords, the civil service and the BBC.The lesson for us low-born, powerless Leavers is to take what we can and scarper before the whole idea is killed stone dead. Which I fear it may be.And now Mrs May is heading back to Brussels to plead for a delay in triggering Article .All along she has been too obsessed with the process of leaving the EU, rather than the clear imperative as demanded by the British people â€” to simply LEAVE the EU, all of it.She has followed Brusselsâ€™ agenda at every twist and turn. And sheâ€™ll be following it now. Sheâ€™ll do what the EU wants.So hereâ€™s the deal, as I see it. Give her hopeless proposal one more chance and this time vote for it.We will have been cheated, but not as badly aswe do not leave at all.Because the longer this goes on, the more likely that outcome will be.THIS country becomes more deranged by the very hour.A Roman Catholic journalist claims she may face JAIL because she referred to a transgendered person by the sex assigned at birth, rather than the one she now identies as.Caroline Farrow has been told she must attend a police station for a taped interview.She said: â€œI have pointed out to police that I am a Catholic journalist commentator and it is my religious belief that a person cannot change sex.â€Quite. Biologists would argue exactly the same.When is this madness going to stop And donâ€™t the Old Bill have better things to do with their time Why should this be  Are they simply delighted theyâ€™re not Swedish Other stats might give us a clue.Finland also has one of the highest rates of alcoholism in the world. And also one of the higher suicide rates.So they rate highly for happiness because a theyâ€™re all perpetually p***ed b the sad ones have all topped themselves.GORGEOUS, pouting Olivia Attwood has been complaining that reality TV stars are prone to mental illness because of the horrible abuse they get online.Perhaps sheâ€™s right. There are some nasty t***ers out there, for sure.But might it not also be the case that reality TV stars are prone to mental illness anyway, without the trolls Being famous just for the sake of being famous appeals to a certain kind of rather fragile, insecure personality, I would reckon.THE Oxford English Dictionary has been updated to include the usual raft of gender words. Such as â€œzirâ€ and â€œhirâ€ and the horrible â€œpeoplekindâ€.I hope they have room next year for these following words Iâ€™ve just made up: Togerov â€“ a Bulgarian man who has transitioned to female.Abbottophobia â€“ the irrational fear that Diane is about to appear on the TV talking complete b******s.Droll â€“ an internet troll who is nonetheless quite funny.WYLFWTSâ€“ someone on a gender studies or media studies course. From the acronym Would You Like Fries With That, Sir IT is time to sort out the gamekeepers â€“ once and for all.A new study has suggested that they are responsible for the illegal killing of one of Britainâ€™s rarest birds, the hen harrier.These scumbags are believed to have killed almost THREE QUARTERS of tagged hen harriers. The killings take place on grouse moors.These moors occupy a vast area of the country.But they are managed for the benefit of a tiny number of iniduals. And the local wildle is destroyed.AMONG the names Scottish people gave to their newborn babies in  were Lucer, Awesome and Adora-belle.I hope Lucer doesnâ€™t feel victimised in what is primarily a Christian country. And I hope Awesome doesnâ€™t end up sleeping rough in Sauchiehall Street with wee seeping out of his trousers.That would be an ironically cruel fate.But itâ€™s good to see that the most popular name in Scotland for boys was Jack. As in the Union Jack.A BUNCH of nutters are off to Antarctica.The Flat Earth Society is planning a trip to the South Pole to prove once and for all that the earth is indeed the shape of a tea tray. Not a globe at all.It thinks thereâ€™s a big ice wall at the edge of Antarctica and itâ€™s impossible to get over.Some of them think that actually the world â€“ and all the stars and planets â€“ are enclosed in a giant dome. A bit like The Truman Show, then.â€œWhy does the moon give out its own light,â€ one of them asked. .I donâ€™t get these people. Everyone knows the world is triangular, with us at the top, followed by all the good, hard-working protestant countries.That was Zain Osmanâ€™s excuse to the court. Well, fair enough. Quite often Iâ€™m disgusted at the immorality in modern Britain.And when that happens I immediately shove my hands down the trousers of the first bloke I see and start tugging on his old fella. Natural reaction, isnâ€™t it Mr Osman arrived here illegally. But he was granted asylum. Shouldnâ€™t he be sent back to tend his flock in the vibrant, go-ahead state of Sudan Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: secret civil servant remain bureaucrats undermine brexit
story: Before joining the service I had believed, naively, that these values would be upheld unconditionally. I quickly came to learn that, in relation to Brexit, nothing could be further from the truth.Unfortunately, I must remain anonymous for fear of the backlash I would receive at my place of work.However, I can reveal I am a senior policy professional within the service and work closely with a number of government departments.There are a number of extremely dangerous myths regarding civil servants that I must dispel because of the impact they are having on the Brexit process.MYTH : The civil service is independent. The civil service was founded on the pillars of political neutrality.Civil servants are meant to ensure that their own political persuasions do not affect their work. Crucially, they should accept those from all political leanings and points of view.It has become clear to me that the vast majority of civil servants support Remain.From my observations I would estimate this number to be well over  per cent.This is worrying in itself and far from representative of the  per cent of the people who voted for Brexit.Most horrying, however, is the sheer disdain and utter contempt that my colleagues display towards people who voted to Leave.I have lost count of the number of insulting and derogatory terms that are used in my own department and where to refer to the .million people who voted for Brexit: â€œRacistâ€, â€œstupidâ€, â€œuneducatedâ€.Anti-Brexit jokes and snide remarks are dropped casually into everyday office con-versations. I live in fear that my colleagues will discover through a slip of my tongue that I am a Brexiteer.Were this to happen, I believe that most would refuse to talk to me again and I might even lose my job.This entire culture creates a thickening cloud of negativity towards Brexit that shades all areas of the civil service. I have witnessed first-hand civil servants doing everything within their power, subtly and under the surface, to frustrate Brexit and talk it down at every opportunity.This can only seriously undermine our efforts to be in the strongest position possible on leaving the EU.MYTH : Civil servants are experts in their field.One would like to think the iniduals making decisions that affect our entire nation would have some level of skill or experience.If only that were true.For example, I know of one stand-alone â€œexpertâ€ policy team leading our preparations for Brexit.You can imagine my disbelief when I discovered none of its members had worked on anything remotely related to the EU before. In fact, I have discovered over time that the vast majority of â€œexpertsâ€ within the service have no expertise whatsoever.In many cases the â€œportfolioâ€ you take on when you join the service is dictated by the one held by your predecessor.As a result, you have new civil servants inheriting politically sensitive and highly important work without the faintest clue about what they are dealing with.Civil servants who are seriously underperforming will usually have a new job title and position created for them somewhere  in the organisation instead of being sacked or performance-managed â€” they become someone â€™s problem then.Given the influence that civil servants are exerting over the Brexit process, this is truly concerning.MYTH : The civil service does not engage in scaremongering.I had hoped that civil servants, even in times of crisis, would be able to remain calm and level-headed in pursuit of ensuring the best outcomes for our country.And yet it is not uncommon for me to receive emails from colleagues promoting Brexit scare stories that are nothing more than lies and speculation. Recently, things have become so panicked that ious â€œBrexit contingencyâ€ plans have been set up throughout the organisation. This is to prepare for the â€œnational public transport breakdownâ€, â€œsurge in criminalityâ€ and â€œwidespread public unrestâ€ that is going to follow after we leave.These plans also involve collecting the personal details of certain civil servants to put in place a -hour, on-call rota for the â€œemergencyâ€ that is looming. This scare-mongering, created and whipped up by civil servants, is having a marked impact on the confidence and well-being of ordinary citizens.For example, one acquain-tance of mine is so terried by the speculative threats put out by the service they have started to stockpile large quantities of their medication. This needs to stop.MYTH : Ministers are in charge.When I was outside the civil service looking in, I always believed civil servants were there simply to advise their ministers, who, as elected representatives of the people, would make the ultimate decision. However, I have come to realise that ministers are often mere puppets, with civil servants pulling ferociously at their strings.The level of bureaucracy is unimaginable.In my experience parlia-mentary briefings go through â€” at a minimum â€” five stages of internal clearance, with crucial information being amended or deleted at every stage on the whim of that inidual civil servant.The power and competence of our ministers is, Iâ€™m afraid, a facade.They are nothing more than a megaphone for the views of biased civil servants who lurk behind them in the shadows.I am a supporter of the Leave campaign.To go against the will of the people expressed in the  referendum would be the ultimate act of betrayal.The Government MUST allow us to take back control by leaving the EU on World Trade Organisation terms. If the people are betrayed, I may have no choice but to resign.Honesty, impartiality, integrity and objectivity. We will soon discover, once and for all, whether our politicians embody these values.Â©The Sunday Times News LicensingÂ Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit deal must offer job face general election
story: Over the next three weeks, all sorts of choices will race into view. You decline to come and talk to us â€” then insult us.â€The Governmentâ€™s domino strategy for winning the vote required getting the DUP to come on board.There is only one way to change this dynamic â€” for May to offer to goher deal passes.This would instantly change the debate. In the past few days, one Tory MP who wants No Deal and another who wants a second referendum told me they would vote for a Â­withdrawal agreementthey had a guarantee she would go.â€œAn increasing number of people are saying their vote is contingent on her going,â€ says a senior backbencher.As one Cabinet minister admits: â€œEven that may not be enough.â€ But without it, thereâ€™s no chance of the deal passing next week.James Forsyth is political editor of The Spectator.AMID all this uncertainty, one thing is looking increasingly clear: Britain will have a new Prime Minister soon.Opinion has turned against Theresa May Â­following her ill-judged speech on Wednesday.â€œShe has managed to offend everybody,â€ one previously loyal minister tells me.And one Secretary of State fumes: â€œSheâ€™s alienated Parliament, the Cabinet and the EU.â€There are no shortage of leadership candidates sounding people out.Jeremy Hunt, the Foreign Secretary, has the support of more Â­Cabinet ministers than anybody . He is seen as a safe pair of hands and as having the Â­emotional intelligence to hold the party together.Sajid Javid was the frontrunner. But as always happens in Tory leadership contests, that has put a target on his back. He has had a dficult few weeks and is losing support.Cabinet ministers are convinced that Andrea Leadsom is running. They point out how, at Cabinet this week, she spoke in a string of highly quotable lines about Leave voters being let down.Liz Truss, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, is also expected to go for it. He is the new toast of the party donor classes, who think he offers competence. One MP describes him as â€œa better version of Jeremy Huntâ€.On the backbenches, Dominic Raab and Boris Johnson are competing to be the Brexiteer Â­candidate. Raabâ€™s campaign is better organised â€“ he has ten MPs gathering support for him.But Johnson has the proven electoral record and greater experience. One thing to remember, though. Tory leadership races are like the Grand National: Messy, unpredictable and the favourite rarely wins.Â THE absurdity of Labourâ€™s Brexit position is that it accepts the withdrawal agreement.What it takes issue with is the political Â­declaration, which isnâ€™t legally binding.Voting through the Brexit deal would not stop Labour from getting to any of the softer Brexit Â­outcomes that it has been proposing in recent months.You could negotiate almost any kind of Brexit from the withdrawal agreement.But Jeremy Corbyn doesnâ€™t want to vote for it because he doesnâ€™t want to vote for a â€œTory Brexitâ€.It would bring the withdrawal agreement, Â­without the political declaration, to the Commons and dare Labour to vote it down.If Labour blinked and the withdrawal agreement passed, we would then be out of the EU and into the transition Â­period.The EU would also be satisfied and consider us to have ratied the agreement.If Labour voted down the withdrawal agreement, then it would be clear what their motives were.IF there is no chance of the Brexit deal Â­passing unless Theresa May promises to go, who can tell her that This is what ministers have been discussing with each other in the past  hours. They think her No aides wonâ€™t, so somebody  needs to.The obvious candidate is Sir Â­Graham Brady, chairman of the  Committee of Tory MPs. Brady is discreet and respected. title: thailand booze ban red light districts close elections bangkok
story: Thailands red light districts, including the citys gogo bars and clubs, looked like ghost towns as a result of the ban.The country is holding its first elections in almost a decade on Sunday and the military rulers banned all sales of alcohol from pm on March  until pm on March , after polls close.Ladyboy strip clubs and lap dancing bars in the Soi Cowboy strip were deserted on Saturday night while bars in the neighbouring Patpong district also did not open for the evening.In the Soi  Nana area, some bars stayed open with signs outside warning tourists that alcohol was unavailable.Brits said the ban had ruined their weekends, with many spending the night in front of the TV instead of bar-hopping.Police patrolled the streets making sure that no holidaymakers were drinking and that supermarkets had stopped selling booze until the elections conclude tomorrow evening at pm.Anyone caught breaking the law can face up to six months in prison and a fine of up to , baht .David Maguire, , from Nottingham, said: Im on a cruise and were only staying in Bangkok for one night.But now theres nothing to do in the evening. I cant even buy a beer to take back to the hotel.So it looks like well be drinking water and watching the telly.Chris Tenreiro, from Leytonstone, east London, said: I was expecting everything to be buzzing on a Saturday night but its like a ghost town.Hopefully itll get back to normal tomorrow and there wont be any problems.The elections - widely regarded by critics as being rigged by the military - are the first time the country has gone to the polls in since the army seized power in  instilling General Prayut Chan-o-cha as leader.The ban that takes place around election times was introduced in September , revising the previous Election Act.Authorities choose to ban alcohol to prevent voting manipulation and bribery, with canvassers previously throwing parties to attract votes at the last minute.It is the first national election in Thailand since , following the military coup in .Andrew MacGregor Marshal, a lecturer at Edinburgh Napier University and author on Thai politics, said: The election will neither be free nor fair. Thai dictator Prayut Chan-ocha and his junta have shamelessly and systematically cheated throughout the election campaign.The Election Commission, which is entrusted with safeguarding the integrity of the polls and ensuring voting goes smoothly, has shown itself to be biased and incompetent.Pro-democracy parties have faced censure for the smallest alleged infractions, while the most blatant cheating by the junta has gone unpunished.For Thais who want true democracy, the situation seems hopeless. Many are questioning whether it is even worth voting.Phuket Provincial Police Deputy Commander Col Sermpan Sirikong toldÂ The Phuket News: The ban on the sale of alcohol is mandatory by law.Police will enforce it that same as we do for the five Buddhist religious days throughout the year.I believe that foreign tourists will understand that this is law must be followed.

title: disneyland paris france evacuated

title: theresa may gone 10 days brexit cabinet
story: The PM has one last throw of the dice to get her Brexit deal through Parliament this week â€“ but that looks doomed to failure.She looks increasingly isolated as even her most loyal allies concluded she has reached the end of the road.A senior Cabinet source said: â€œDespite all the ideological splits over Brexit, we are now united on one front â€“ we all think Theresa needs to go.â€But Mrs May has a last-gasp plan to rally rebel Tories behind her hated deal and stay at Number .Sources say she will await the outcome of this weekâ€™s â€œpick â€˜nâ€™ mixâ€ vote in which MPs choose a solution to the Brexit deadlock from a menu of seven.They are certain to choose a â€œsofterâ€ Brexit, probably staying in the customs union and requiring a two-year extension of Article .Mr May would then spring a snap Commons vote, forcing MPs to decide between that and her deal.She hopes it will force hardline Brexiteers back in line â€“ making her the hero of the hour.But she is pinning her hopes on Speaker John Bercow â€“ a self-confessed Remainer â€“ allowing her one last vote.Last night a senior Cabinet minister told The Sun on Sunday: â€œYou have to admire her resilience.â€œTheresa has surprised everyone with her tenacity but now itâ€™s Brexit or bust. If she backed a two-year delay, the other half would walk out.The multi-choice vote on the best way forward is expected on Wednesday will almost certainly demand an extension beyond June  â€“ which the PM has already insisted was unacceptable.A senior MP said: â€œShe has less than three weeks to tell the EU what her next step is. If itâ€™s an extension she is finished. Nobody is going to let her stay on the get us out of this mess.â€The only formal process to remove her is a no-confidence vote of the  committee of MPs. But their failed bid to topple her in December means they cannot try again for a year.That means she has to be persuaded to resign â€“ or brought down by a general election.Some angry MPs are suggesting the â€œnuclear optionâ€ a â€œVote strikeâ€ until she gets the message.Mrs Mayâ€™s allies yesterday warned that politics will be in meltdown unless they come to their senses and back the deal.THERESA May has been accused of being the Sven-Goran Eriksson of politics - having no Plan B.The PM has failed to set out another route out of the Brexit chaos remaining tight-lipped when quizzed this week by EU leaders.The Swede, who managed England between  and , was accused for not having a rescue strategy by pundits.Mrs May has written to all MPs to indicate she may not bring back her dealit canâ€™t command enough support to secure victory.One Minister said: â€œLike Sven, she has no plan B when things go wrong. She just keeps moving the goal posts. She has now lost control of her dressing room.â€œShe has been running down the clock but now the EU have blown the whistle.â€Mrs May refused to sack Remain-backing Cabinet Ministers including Amber Rudd when she defied the party to keep no deal off the table infuriating colleagues.Another Minister added: â€œEveryday you hope the PM and Number  canâ€™t make it any worse and then they do.â€Hardline Brexiteers insist the PM should enact the law as it stands and leave without a deal when the deadline is reached at pm on Friday.But by agreeing to extend Article  last week EU chiefs have trumped UK law so it is now impossible to crash out.A Brexit-backing minister said: â€œLots of Eurosceptics are thinking â€˜one more push and weâ€™ll get it over the line by Fridayâ€™ but the truth is they wonâ€™t.â€œA communique released by the European Commission last week has changed the rules.â€œSo evenwe have carried out all the legislation required to leave the EU, that will be trumped by international law which dictates that the extension to Article  takes precedence.â€Another pro-Brexit minister added: â€œCanâ€™t they see that their Brexit dream is sinking before their eyes â€œThey are behaving like passengers on the Titanic, who can see the ship going down but refuse to join a leboat and stand there pointing at the guarantee on the main deck.â€Cabinet discipline has broken down with Business Secretary Greg Clark being accused â€œfreelancingâ€ when he announced the PM would back a series of indicative votes.One minister said: â€œNumber  are furious as his attempt to bounce her into it. If she ends up having to go through with it, there will be some pretty angry people on the back benches, too.â€If MPs seize control of the process this week, Mrs May could give Tories a free vote.Former minister Mark Francois, vice chairman of the European Research Group, said is proved she had given up the ghost on leading the country.He declared: â€œIf the government of this country does not have a view on how to proceed and the most important question facing Britain since the end of the second world war then, in effect, we no longer have a government, just a collection of iniduals who call themselves ministers of the crown.Despite her best intentions and a dogged determination to see Brexit through, the chances of her deal ever getting Commons support are pitiably low.Some senior ministers put the likelihood of it passing next week at  per cent.The PM has seen her own authority seep away and is now unable to uny her own Cabinet, let alone the party in general.That means she is powerless even to call an election.As the  Committee chairman Sir Graham Brady points out here, her deal may be threadbare but it still offers the only realistic chance of Brexit actually taking place.Backing it would give Britain a chance of a new start. If the deal fails again it seems Philip Hammond and David Lidington will be knocking on the PMâ€™s door to tell her the time has come to make an exit.But in the midst of this paralysing crisis even that is not an easy option.There is no clear route to appointing a successor in the short term. title: settle brexit mess leave eu with deal
story: Something as simple as taking back control of our own country has been made to look impossibly complicated.Nation states around the globe make their own laws and trade successfully with or without free trade agreements. The UK itself has been more successful in recent years in growing its trade with markets outside the EU than with those that are inside the single market and customs union.It baffles me that so many British politicians have so little faith in Britain that they think we would be sunkwe had to stand on our own two feet.The mistakes that have brought us to this point are well known: agreeing to decide the terms of the Withdrawal Agreement before settling the future trading relationship with the EU agreeing to a â€œbackstopâ€ to prevent a â€œhard borderâ€ in Ireland allowing the militant Remainers in Parliament to damage Britainâ€™s negotiating position by taking â€œNo Dealâ€ off the table and allowing our exit date to be deferred.If only we had accepted the EUâ€™s offer two years ago to have a big Canada-Plus free trade agreement, we could have locked in certainty for business and spent the last two years trying to improve upon it!The question now is whatâ€™s the best way to achieve the proper Brexit that the British people voted for nearly three years ago I understand why so many of my Tory and DUP friends have voted against the PMâ€™s deal. I told her in November the â€œbackstopâ€ made it impossible for anyone who wanted to leave the EU to vote for it: it could lock the UK into the EU customs union for ever.That is why I voted against it the first time. Itâ€™s also why I tabled the â€œBrady amendmentâ€ â€” which was voted through at the end of January, telling the PM to go back and ensure the â€œbackstopâ€ couldnâ€™t become a permanent trap.When the Governmentâ€™s lawyer Geoffrey Cox said the changes agreed would allow a way out in most circumstanceswe were faced with a tough choice.To take a risk and support the deal or keep voting against, hoping something better would emerge. It was defeated a second time, with a big majority against.Those of us who really want Brexit to happen and British politics to be able to get on with other things are now faced with taking a massive political judgment.By voting for the pretty threadbare deal Theresa May brought back from Brussels, we can ensure some sort of Brexit and then a new negotiating team that believes in what itâ€™s doing can work to get something worthwhile out of the future relationship after we have left.If we donâ€™t vote the deal through this week, it no longer looks like Theresaâ€™s promise that â€œno deal is better than a bad dealâ€ will be honoured. Two years ago,  per cent of you voted for a political party â€” whether Tory or Labour â€” that promised to implement the referendum decision.Two years on Labour is angling for a second referendumand lots of other MPs are pushing for a Brexit that amounts to staying in. Some want endless delay, a few are at least honest enough to admit they really want to ignore the decision of . million voters altogether.Meanwhile, the EU is creaking. Just as the EU is set for crisis, this country is poised for success.British businesses are sitting on big cash balances but are crying out for the certainty that will allow them to invest.If we deliver on our promise to leave in the coming weeks, Britain will prosper. If we get stuck in the departure lounge, our country will suffer.For heavenâ€™s sake, letâ€™s settle this now.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit mess britain stuck lame duck prime minister
story: The Prime Minister finds herself in the worst of all worlds.Despite her best intentions and a dogged determination to see Brexit through, the chances of her deal ever getting Commons support are pitiably low.Some senior ministers put the likelihood of it passing next week at  per cent.The PM has seen her own authority seep away and is now unable to uny her own Cabinet, let alone the party in general.That means she is powerless even to call an election.As the  Committee chairman Sir Graham Brady points out here, her deal may be threadbare but it still offers the only realistic chance of Brexit actually taking place.Backing it would give Britain a chance of a new start. If the deal fails again it seems Philip Hammond and David Lidington will be knocking on the PMâ€™s door to tell her the time has come to make an exit.But in the midst of this paralysing crisis even that is not an easy option.There is no clear route to appointing a successor in the short term. And with the party at loggerheads even a swt transition to a caretaker PM is perilous.After this weekâ€™s turmoil we face being stuck for some time with a lame-duck Prime Minister, whoever it may be.Britain needs a miracle to avoid it.The crushing of IS in Syria is a massive achievement.Defeating this self-proclaimed caliphate is the beginning of the end for a reign of terror which has claimed , lives and spawned , attacks over four bloody years.The courage and sacrice of the Â­Western-backed forces that fought so fiercely to drive the jihadis from their final stronghold has been rightly praised by Theresa May.But she was also wise to caution that the ousting of the religious fanatics from their territory will not end the risk they pose.Many hardened fighters will go to ground in the area so they can continue to wage guerrilla warfare.Other dangerous extremists will no doubt flee to Europe and even to this country, still fuelled by their murderous hatred of the West.Like the mythical hydra with its many heads, cutting off one risks generating others in its place.Our security forces must now be on alert for a fresh wave of Islamic-inspired terror closer to home.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. James McGrory, the director of the Peopleâ€™s Vote campaign and one of the organisers of the march, said the campaign for a second Brexit referendum is now the biggest mass movement in Britain, dwarfing the membership of the main political parties. â€œPeople from all walks of le see can what they were once offered bears no relation to what is being delivered and they are angry about it because it feels like a bad deal is being rammed down their throats,â€ he told Reuters. But itâ€™s more than that, we want to see all of our relatives. We are all over the place. â€œItâ€™s Europe we want to be part of. We are European you canâ€™t take it out of us.â€ Leaders agreed to extend Brexit to May Mrs May can get MPs to back her deal in the Commons at the third time of asking. If the vote is not passed, the UK will have to set out an alternative way forward by April , which could mean a much longer delay - with the UK required to hold elections to the European Parliament - or leaving without a deal at all.

title: woman ended up marrying convicted
story: NewsWoman ended up marrying convicted killer after answering a newspaper advertEXCLUSIVE: Val Thatcher was  when she first started writing to George, a convicted killer. And now she wants to prove his innocenceShareCommentsByOlivia Buxton:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsVal with a painting of George he had painted "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who answered an ad from a convicted murderer ended up marrying him â€“ and spent years trying to clear his name. Val Thatcher was a -year-old orced teacher way back in  when she first started writing to the man who would become her second husband. George Thatcher was serving le for shooting a worker dead in an armed robbery on a Co-op dairy, a crime for which he was originally condemned to be hanged. And as the unlikely pair corresponded, and then met over the next six years in jails around the country, their relationship gradually blossomed into romance. Astonishingly, it eventually led to a -year marriage that lasted until George died from a stroke in .  Â  Today retired Val tells how she always believed George, a petty thief and safeblower, was framed for the killing for which he served  years. And a TV show re-examining the case could shed new light on it as modern-day legal experts give it their consideration. A team of barristers will st through evidence from the time and look at question marks over a verbal confession â€“ potentially flagging up a miscarriage of justice. Val, now , said: â€œI have read George was a man addicted to unreasonable violence, which is so untrue. He was such a gentle person. He wouldnâ€™t have hurt a fly. â€œIt was all an image that was painted of him that just wasnâ€™t true. â€œEven now, I still canâ€™t help but be upset because of the injustice of what happened to him and the years wasted because of it.â€  Â  Val first made contact with George when he was doing time in HMP Albany on the Isle of Wight. Frustrated by what he claimed was his wrongful imprisonment, he had placed an advert in the upmarket magazine New Statesman and it caught Valâ€™s eye. She recalled: â€œThe best thing I ever did was to reply to his advert, which read. â€˜Ler, aspiring dramatist and painter seeks new outlets through communication and visitsâ€™. â€œMy reaction was â€˜Gosh, there is somebody worse off than meâ€™. I felt sorry for him so I wrote him a letter. â€œWomen might write to prisoners to get a kick, but there was none of that prurient fascination â€“ because I had no idea when I replied to the ad what George was supposed to have done. â€œWe exchanged a few letters before I went to visit him a couple of months later. I was very nervous because I had never been inside a prison before but George was so kind and gentle, very dferent from what I was expecting. â€œHe was a wonderful artist and I sent him photos of London because he loved to paint street scenes. He loved creative writing too and had written a play The Only Way Out.  Â  â€œThe manuscript was smuggled out of prison in a painting and was performed at the Royal Court Theatre in London in , which I encouraged people to watch. â€œIt was only when I began toabout the case that I understood it. He always protested his innocence in prison and when I really got to know him, I started to believe him. â€œHe really didnâ€™t seem like an armed robber or a killer.â€ George was born in  into a childhood of abject poverty and by his s was a career criminal with a string of convictions. On November , , a gang of robbers struck at the Royal Arsenal Co-op in Mitcham, Surrey, and stole Â£. Detectives called to the scene found the managerâ€™s office ransacked and the safe plundered. Outside, a depot vehicle sat abandoned with its window shot out. And a Co-op employee, father-of-two Dennis Hurden, lay leless at the entrance.  Within hours a getaway car had been found and soon three men, Philip Kelly, John Hilton and Charles Connelly, had been arrested. Kelly gave cops the name of George Thatcher, who denied not only that he shot Mr Hurden but that he had even been on the raid. There was no scientic evidence linking him with the crime and no ID parade was held. The key evidence used against George were statements from police, who testied that he had implicated himself.George was found guilty at the Old Bailey on March ,  of an offence known at the time as capital murder, which carried a mandatory death penalty. His co-accused Kelly, Hilton and Connelly were all convicted of murder and jailedfor le.Less than a month after the trial Georgeâ€™s sentence of execution was commuted to le imprisonment. And though he avoided the hangmanâ€™s rope he still spent nearly two decades locked up for a crime Val is still convinced he did not commit.  Â  Val, who was living near Bristol at the time, said: â€œI never believed that writing to George would end up in us getting married but I wanted to offer him my support. â€œWhen we first met he was in Albany and then Parkhurst, where Ronnie Biggs and Mad Frankie Fraser were. Then he was transferred to Coldingley in Surrey, Gartree near Northampton and finally to Leyhill in Gloucestershire. â€œAfter a couple of years I realised I was falling in love and George told me he felt the same. â€œWhen he got to Leyhill he was allowed occasional phone calls and it was quite easy for him to sneak out. We could meet at night and be romantic.â€Val even took her daughter Marion along on visits and George would give her bars of chocolate and toys he had made himself. She added: â€œBy then I couldnâ€™t reallyÂ  imagine my le without George.â€œHe was recommended twice for parole and turned down by the Home Office but I grew determined to win his release and I wrote to more and more people. â€œI became Georgeâ€™s leline and his window to the outside world.â€œFast-forward to  and his release from prison and our wedding were the two happiest days of my le.â€œWe got married at Bath register office and everyone I taught with at the school turned up.â€ To start a new le, the couple bought a derelict house in Co Kerry in Ireland, spent years renovating it and eventually moved out there full-time. Val added: â€œWe rarely spoke about what happened and we burned all of our letters along with the manuscript from the trial. It felt cathartic.â€  Sadly when George was  he was diagnosed with pulmonary fibrosis. Val left their home because it held too many memories but went back to scatter Georgeâ€™s ashes and film for the BBCâ€™s Murder, Mystery and My Family.The show tells Georgeâ€™s story, with QCs Sasha Wass and Jeremy Dein examining all the facts relating to the case. Val added: â€œLosing George left a big hole in my le. I spent  years fightinghis corner and it has been very, very hard to readjust.â€ Murder, Mystery and My Family is on BBC One, weekdays at .am.

title: film project helping to put favourite books in spotlight at aberdeen library
story: Library lovers have been sharing their passions as part of a new initiative that combines books and film.Reel Futures asked members of the public to talk about their favourite books, media or the library service and why they loved it.The special event, held at Aberdeenâ€™s Central Library on Saturday, gave participants the chance to share their stories.The project,  Second Stories, was open to people of all ages and will be used as part of a larger initiative to promote Aberdeen City Library Service.Marianne Noble, , came along to the event with three-year-old daughter Stella and spoke about the importance of libraries in communities.She said: â€œThere are plenty of books for people, but the space here is also a resource.â€œIt is a space where people can come in the city and spend some time, especially when you have kids.â€ vw, px"  Christine Strachan, a librarian at the nearby Robert Gordonâ€™s College, said she was glad to take part and share her love of books.She said: â€œI saw it originally on social media and it asked people to come down and talk about why the library was important to you and about your favourite book. I felt a connection to it and was quite happy to take part.â€œIt isnâ€™t just about books. The library as a space itself is hugely important. I think we often forget that not everybody in society has access to smartphones and computers.â€œFor those people,they want to apply for a job or search for information, or maybe just pay a bill online, it is a vital space for them to do that.â€Christine also used the event to sing the praises of her favourite novel â€“ Moby Dick by Herman Melville.She said: â€œIt is often described as the greatest American novel ever written. I also think it is a great adventure story.â€œI loved the characters. They are really obsessed about something and wouldnâ€™t stop until they had done what they set out to achieve.â€œIâ€™ve read it once properly but sometimes I will go back and pick it up and read a chapter here or there.â€Reel Futures project manager Andrew Davidson said: â€œThe aim of the project is to enable young people to take charge and control of film projects.â€œIt isnâ€™t just about the filming â€“ it also promotes working together as a group and planning, as well as helping their employability skills.â€œThe project has been really good. Iâ€™m really pleased with the work the volunteers have done. They took charge and did all the interviews. Weâ€™ve had great statements from people about their experiences and it has been positive.â€ vw, px"  Youngsters Ribh Oâ€™Neill, Ben Lunney, Luke Dempster and Dylan Shearer were behind the cameras.Dylan, , who goes to Aberdeen Grammar School, said he hopes the experience will help him take a step closer to his dream job.He said: â€œIâ€™d love to be director one day and there arenâ€™t many opportunities for filming and directing in Aberdeen.â€œThis was a once-in-a-blue-moon opportunity and Iâ€™m happy Iâ€™ve taken it. It has given me more experience and Iâ€™m pretty proud of that.â€œMy favourite part has been meeting all the dferent people and talking about what the library means to them.â€Diary of a Wimpy Kid and Lego films are top picks from Aberdeen#s libraries in " src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local diary-of-a-wimpy-kid-and-lego-films-are-top-picks-from-aberdeens-libraries-in- embed # secretNHPRIVXe" data-secret"NHPRIVXe" width"" "" title"#Diary of a Wimpy Kid and Lego films are top picks from Aberdeen#s libraries in # # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: northern lights may be visible in north east tonight
story: A solar storm is on its way to Earth â€“ and that could mean the Northern Lights will be visible in the skies above the north-east tonight.The Met Office said the best place in the UK to see the phenomenon, known as the aurora borealis, may be Aberdeenshire.Bonnie Diamond, meteorologist at the Met Office, said: â€œA Coronal Mass Ejection has happened and the effects of that are expected to arrive later tonight. This type of active geomagnetic storm means that there is the possibility of the aurora borealis, commonly known as the Northern Lights.â€œWhether or not you will see the Northern Lights depends on where you are and what the weather is like. Scotland is where youâ€™re most likely to see it.â€œThereâ€™s a couple of showers on the west coast of Scotland tonight.â€œHowever, the clearest skies are further east in Aberdeenshire, where cloud cover will be minimal.â€œFurther north, youâ€™re pretty likely to see something.â€

title: place your bids now charlie house auction to help build specialist support centre in aberdeen
story: Artwork created by children could raise thousands of pounds for a charity.Aberdeen wealth management firm Mattioli Woods is taking part in Venture , which challenges teams to raise as much money as possible from a starting sum of Â£.All the cash from Venture will go towards supporting Charlie Houseâ€™s plans to build a state-of-the-art specialist support centre in Aberdeen.The team from Mattioli Woods came up with the idea of a canvas they could auction off and turned to children, siblings and parents who are supported by Charlie House to help create the artwork.They were asked to draw something inspired by the theme â€˜homeâ€™, then all the artworks were combined to make a landscape design of the Granite City.Mattioli Woods worked with FortyTwo Studio to produced the final image, which is now being auctioned.The Evening Express currently has the leading bid of Â£, on the online auction.George Gray is leading a team of six at Mattioli Woods.He said they were delighted with the response since opening the bids for the canvas on Tuesday.George said: â€œOur plan is to get the canvas displayed at ious locations throughout the city in the coming weeks before the end of the auction.â€œWe thought it would be a great idea to get the children of Charlie House involved, and the idea just snowballed.â€œWe came up with the children doing a picture with the theme of home and what is special to them about Charlie House.â€œWeâ€™ve pulled all those images into one giant image for the north-east.â€George added: â€œThe canvas is .m long and is a metre tall. When people see it they will be able to pick out the landmarks.â€œThe Evening Express has kindly put in a bid of Â£, and is currently the highest bidder,â€ he said.â€œWe also had an anonymous bid of Â£, we received the other day as well. To get two massive bids on it already is fantastic.â€Venture, an Apprentice-style challenge, is taking place to raise money for Charlie Houseâ€™s Big Build Appeal.The judging  is to include local entrepreneur Bob Keiller, with one of the prizes being tickets to attend his Effective Business Storytelling workshop.There will be one team crowned winner, as well as additional awards handed out.The new Charlie House centre is expected to cost Â£ million to build and maintain and would be set in four acres at Woodend Hospital.It will include eight childrenâ€™s bedrooms with family accommodation, as well as facilities, including a craft room, teen den, sensory gardens and office space for employees.The winner of Venture will be announced on Thursday.The auction will end on May .

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of Â£m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at Â£.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of Â£m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and Â£m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK governmentâ€™s proposed use of the armyâ€™s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea itâ€™s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby

The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didnâ€™t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. title: john crawford ardrishaig
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Refereesâ€™ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. As a couple they were permanent fixtures at most shinty events in Argyll and well beyond, particularly at events involving young players.Tribute reproduced courtesy of the Camanachd Association

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this â€“ why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: bob shields public need say
story: NewsBob Shields: Public need say on Prime Ministers Brexit dealReal democracy is having a second voteShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsBlundering Theresa May heads the most incompetent Government weve had in living memory "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHow many Members of Parliament does it take to change a light bulb  The answer â€“ of course - is just one. But it takes the other  of them over two and a half years to decide exactly what kind of light bulb they want in its place! In last weekâ€™s episode of Commons Comedy Capers, we had the Brexit secretary proposing the Governmentâ€™s motion . . . then voting against it. Similarly, we had the Chief Whip â€“ whose job is make sure MPs toe the party line â€“ voting against his party line! Last Tuesday MPs rejected Theresa Mayâ€™s deal, on Wednesday the rejected â€˜No Dealâ€™ and on Thursday they rejected sticking to the March  deadline. I watched the creaking, croaking Theresa at Prime Ministerâ€™s Questions and it looked like the only thing you could guarantee to be behind May . . . was June! When it comes to Brexit, the House of Commons has now had more votes than most Eurovision Song Contests. And as I write this on a dreary Monday afternoon â€“ it seems certain that another vote is on the way. Theresa May is going to put her â€˜dealâ€™ to the Commons for a THIRD time . . . but onlysheâ€™s confident that sheâ€™ll win it! Yes folks â€“ a vote ONLYshe knows sheâ€™ll win in advance. Howâ€™s that for democracy at work  So - we have a vote . . . another vote . . . and then another vote  Mmm â€“ now where have I heard that before  Ah yes â€“ now I remember - itâ€™s been the Conservative partyâ€™s official â€˜put downâ€™ of every single request for a second â€œpeopleâ€™s referendumâ€ on Brexit. Itâ€™s a line you can even trace it back to the lips of our very own Member of Parliament, Mr Bill Grant. â€œWe have already had a â€˜peopleâ€™s voteâ€, he said. â€œAnother vote, assuming it indicated a dferent outcome, would be presumably followed by another vote and another vote, and so onâ€. What Bill, and the Conservatives, have been telling us for months is that you canâ€™t keep on having a vote until you get the result you want. But meanwhile, the leader of the Conservative party is doing exactly that! And itâ€™s not asthe Prime Minister needs a five per cent swing â€“ the dference in the Euro referendum â€“ to get her own way. It beggars belief that she can take the biggest parliamentary hiding in history . . .and go back for a second and even a third bite at the cherry! It begs the obvious question â€“our MPs can get three chances to vote on the biggest political issue of our generation â€“ why canâ€™t the â€˜peopleâ€™ get at least a second vote  Iâ€™m also getting fed up with Brexiteers telling us â€œthe public just want this pushed over theline so they can move onâ€.Er . . . no. The public I speak to want the right deal to leave Europe. Anditâ€™s not on the table, theywant the right to reject it and stay in Europe. Is it too late to ask Bill Grant to stop puckering in the direction of Theresa May and start pointing his ears in the direction of his constituency, which not only voted to â€œremainâ€ but voted him to Parliament to represent them  I hope not. Billâ€™s qualities might include loyalty . . . but heâ€™s always open minded. My solution  Well, it might be a bit simplistic â€“ but then most solutions are.  Parliament instructs the PM to ask to delay Article  for one year.  Parliament instructs the PM to form a cross-party Brexit Committee to begin new talks â€“ and come back with the best deal that the combined parties have negotiated and will have support in Parliament.  Give the public an unbiased and detailed explanation of what the deal means. Put it to a referendum â€“ accept the deal and leave â€“ or reject the deal and remain. This way, the people of Britain - and Europe - will know exactly where they stand.By March   â€“ weâ€™re in or weâ€™re out. And everyone, on every side, will have had their say. Bill, thatâ€™s real democracy at work.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnConservative PartyAyrBrexit

That is why we have gone back out to them to respond to the queries and confusion that have been generated by the community councilâ€™s letter. â€œWe fully appreciate that the community council may have a view on the consultation, which is why colleagues are meeting with them next week and weâ€™re happy to keep them informed about the consultation and engagement process. â€œHowever, our focus â€“ which was clearly expressed by tenants at the recent River Ayr Tenants Association meeting â€“ has to be on hearing the views of those who will be directly affected by Councillorsâ€™ decisions later this year: the tenants of Riverside Place. â€œWe thank them for their participation in the consultation and I can reassure them that their views will be taken into account before any decisions are taken about the future of Riverside Place.â€ Joe Lafferty, Chair of the River Ayr Tenants Association, said: â€œWe have worked closely with the Council over the last couple of years as discussions around the future of the flats have moved forward â€“ and we very much appreciate the approach the Council has taken. â€œIt is for every tenant to consider what is the best option for them and to ensure their voice is heard by those who will be making the decisions about what happens next. Clear facts, easy to understand information and answers to the questions tenants have is whatâ€™s needed and thatâ€™s exactly what we have got from the Council.â€Â Â  Feedback from the consultation will be considered by Councillors in June this year.Full details of the Riverside Place consultation are available atÂ  www.south-ayrshire.gov.uk riverside-place . story: NewsPlans for luxury flats at Prestwicks Malcolm Sargent House are scrappedDevelopers have dropped their proposal to build on the famous site at the seafront.ShareByPaul Behan:,  MAR NewsArchitects plans for the retirement flats "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPlans to build luxury flats at the former Malcolm Sargent holiday retreat for sick kids in Prestwick have been binned. The Post can exclusively reveal that the developers McCarthy  Stone have thrown in the towel and withdrawn their multi-million pound proposals. Major question marks hang over the buildingâ€™s future following the bombshell announcement. The news prompted an angry backlash from Derek Hart, chair of Prestwick North Community Council. In an extraordinary outburst he claimed the building has been â€œplundered and left to rot.â€ The building provided a retreat for children battling cancer for more than  years. It was opened by Princess Diana in . In  it was sold by owners Clic Sargent after claims of a â€œchallenging fundraising environmentâ€. They sold it to McCarthy  Stone and trousered Â£.m from the deal. However, since McCarthy  Stone took ownership and unveiled their luxury flat plans they have been embroiled in a bitter fight with neighbours Prestwick Golf Club. The club was opposed to the development on the basis of its scale and design. In addition, there were fears that errant balls could smash into residentsâ€™ properties. Plans involved building  flats for people aged over , spread out in a T-shape over four floors. The proposals were approved by South Ayrshire Council but last year Prestwick Golf Club successfully petitioned for a judicial review, meaning demolition work on the former retreat had to stop.
