We need a new PM who can reach out  build some sort of coalition for a PlanB.mdash George Freeman MPMarch , ldquoEveryone feels betrayed. Governmentrsquos gridlocked. Trust in democracy collapsing. This canrsquot go on. We need a new PM who can reach outbuild some sort of coalition for a PlanB.Pro-EU former education secretary Nicky Morgan told the Sundaythat Cabinet ministers should tell Mrs May ldquoitrsquos time to go, while Brexiteer Steve Baker said potential leadership contenders in the Government should ldquoact now.Tory backbencher Anne-Marie Trevelyan wrote in the same paper: ldquoWe now need a leader who believes in our country and wants to take her on the next stage of her journey.Conservative peer Lord Gadhia, a former member of David Cameronrsquos inner circle, said the upcoming days in Parliament may be ldquovery dramatic and could see the end of Mrs Mayrsquos time as premier.The Sunday Times reported  Cabinet ministers had told the paper they wanted Mrs May to make way for someone  and that Mr Lidington was in line to take over the helm.But the Mail on Sunday reported ministers were plotting to install Environment Secretary Michael Gove as a caretaker leader.The Chancellor said Parliament would be given the chance to hold indicative votes on alternatives to Mrs Mayrsquos Brexit deal this week.ldquoOne way or another Parliament is going to have the opportunity this week to decide what it is in favour of, and I hope that it will take that opportunity ndashit canrsquot get behind the Prime Ministerrsquos deal ndash to say clearly and unambiguously what it can get behind, he said.But Mr Hammond said a decision had not yet been made on whether Tories would be given a free vote on the matter.After hundreds of thousands of people descended on Parliament on Saturday demanding a so-called Peoplersquos Vote, he said a second referendum was a ldquoperfectly coherent position which ldquodeserves to be considered along with the other proposals.

title: voting-over-in-long-awaited-thailand-election
story: Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, the blunt-speaking army chief who led the  coup, is hoping to extend his hold on power after engineering a new political system that aims to stle the influence of big political parties not aligned with the military.Voting stations closed at pm and meaningful results were expected within several hours, but the formation of a new government could take weeks of haggling.About  million Thais were eligible to vote. Leaders of political parties opposed to military rule urged a high turnout as the only way to derail Mr Prayuthrsquos plans.Mr Prayuth was among the first to vote in Bangkok, the capital, arriving in a black Mercedes after polling booths opened at am.ldquoI hope everyone helps each other by going to vote today as itrsquos everyonersquos right, he told reporters after voting. He played golf later in the morning before heading to an army base to await results.The election is the latest chapter in a nearly two-decade struggle between conservative forces including the military and the political machine of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, a tycoon who upended tradition-bound Thailandrsquos politics with a populist political revolution.Mr Thaksin was ousted in a  military coup and now lives in exile abroad to avoid a prison term, but parties allied with him have won every election since .His sister, Yingluck Shinawatra, who led the government that was ousted in , also fled the country after what supporters said was a politically motivated corruption prosecution.After the coup, political party gatherings were banned and pro-democracy activists and other dissenters were regularly arrested, interrogated and imprisoned. Just days before Sundayrsquos election, the Thaksin-allied Pheu Thai party said the houses of party officials and its campaign canvassers in some provinces were searched by military personnel in an act of intimidation.The partyrsquos leader, Sudarat Keyuraphan, said after voting in Bangkokrsquos Ladprao district that she was confident of winning.ldquoI donrsquot say itrsquoll be a landslide. I donrsquot know. Depends on the people. But I think we can win this election, she said.Thailandrsquos powerful King Maha Vajiralongkorn issued a statement on the eve of the election that said the role of leaders is to stop ldquobad people from gaining power and causing chaos.It was also broadcast on Thai television stations minutes before voting started.Invoking a speech by his father, the previous Thai king who died in  after reigning for seven decades, King Vajiralongkorn said not all citizens can be transformed into good people so leaders must be given support in ruling to create a peaceful nation.He urged government officials, soldiers and civil servants to look after national security.It was the monarchrsquos second notable intervention in politics recently. Last month, he demanded his sister Princess Ubolratana Mahidol withdraw as a prime ministerial candidate for a small Thaksin-allied party within  hours of her announcement.

title: call-to-crack-down-on-unqualified-scots-identifying-as-electricians
story: Tory Jamie Halcro Johnston described the lack of regulation in the profession as an ldquoanomaly and has urged the Scottish Government to take action to ensure the title of electrician is protected in law.Over  professions are currently protected in law, including registered gas engineers, but not electricians.Mr Halcro Johnston said that he will introduce a membersrsquo bill to the Scottish Parliament aiming to address the issue.In a debate on the subject in October, MSPs from across the parties at Holyrood gave their support for providing protection of title.Mr Halcro Johnston said: ldquoFor too long, the Scottish Government has dithered around the regulation of electricians.ldquoIt has been discussed and discussed again, without any real commitments ever seeing the light of day.ldquoWhen I speak to people about this campaign, the first reaction is usually surprise that anyone can call themselves an electrician without any qualication.ldquoWhen so many other trades and professions are regulated, it seems the position of electricians is more of an anomaly than anything .ldquoMost people donrsquot consult electricians on a regular basis and arenrsquot always confident about the qualications of people they employ. This should provide some additional protection to consumers.ldquoElectrical safety is vitally important. Every year, there are fatalities caused by electric shocks and fires caused by electrical mals. It is important that people carrying out electrical work are qualied and able to do so.ldquoI was pleased to get so much support from across the political parties when this was debated back in October and I would hope that support would carry across to introducing a Bill on the subject.Skills Minister Jamie Hepburn said: ldquoThe serious concerns raised about electricians are being considered fully and we are committed to continuing to work in partnership with all stakeholders.ldquoDuring a debate in Parliament in October last year, I offered to meet with any MSPs to discuss these issues further. Whilst others have made contact, Mr Halcro Johnston has not taken up this offer.ldquoFollowing calls for further regulation, we formed the Electricians Working Group to bring the industry together and attempt to build consensus for a way forward.ldquoAn independent analysis of research, leading to a risk assessment and business case on the way forward, is due to be presented to the Scottish Government later in March.

title: we-are-f-says-official-report-on-impact-of-brexit-on-rural-scotland
story: A document published by Scottish Rural Actionfeatured a side banner on page four with the statement.It was one of a number of banners attributed to participants in a workshop which asked them to imagine what newspaper headlines they might expect to see after Brexit.Amanda Burgauer, SRA chairwoman, said that the exercise had been used as an ldquoicebreaker and that several of the participants had used ldquoearthy language in describing their feelings towards Brexit.The comments are only explained on the following page, saying they had been put forward by those taking part in the workshop event.Ms Burgauer said that she would flag up the ldquodesign and layout issue with the SRA design team.The Scottish Government has said that although the SRA report was funded through its Brexit Stakeholder Fund, it had no editorial role.The report will be launched at an SRA event with cabinet secretaries Mike Russell and Richard Lochhead in Elgin on Monday.Its findings also detailed the potential impact of Brexit on rural Scotland, suggesting that it could lead to ldquost century clearances, with a loss of freedom of movement resulting in signicant depopulation.Further concerns raised in the report, taken from conversations with rural communities, also included the risk of EU funding being lost post-Brexit and potential damage to social cohesion.Speaking about the report overall, Ms Burgauer said: ldquoThis report is about giving voice to a rural point of view that is rooted in Scotlandrsquos people and places, rather than its rural industries.She added: ldquoThere is widespread anger and frustration across rural Scotland, but that anger isnrsquot solely about Brexit.ldquoIt was clear from workshop discussions that Brexit is compounding long standing concerns about rural equity and fragility.ldquoBrexit was described as the lsquostraw that breaks rural Scotlandrsquos backrsquo, with people pointing to structural fragilities across rural communities.ldquoParticipants generally believed that an historic over-reliance on EU funding to lsquoprop uprsquo rural areas makes rural Scotland particularly exposed to future loss of EU support.Speaking ahead of the reportrsquos launch, Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to ensuring the voices of rural communities are heard and I commend Scottish Rural Action for the work it has done to achieve this.ldquoThe findings in this report are stark. Taking Scotland out of the EU against our will removes us from a market which is eight times bigger than the UK alone.ldquoRural communities are deeply worried about the impact of Brexit on their lives. From funding and trade to community le and the workforce, many believe the effects will be nothing short of catastrophic.ldquoThis is sadly yet another example of just how damaging Brexit will be for Scotland.A UK Government spokesman said: ldquoThriving rural areas with strong, sustainable economies and vibrant communities will continue to be a priority for the UK Government when we leave the EU.ldquoWe have committed to establishing a UK Shared Prosperity Fund, which will cover Scotland, to increase productivity in areas where the local economies are furthest behind.ldquoWe have also confirmed that we will maintain the same cash total in funds for farm support until the end of the Parliament.

title: who-are-scotlands-favourite-60-bands
story: THE ASSOCIATESWhat do you want from pop music  Maybe you are after a band who can be your best mate  Or a group who will teach you how to think. Or a band who will be a cartoon version of that better band from the sixties. But whatyou want something more  Something rich and strange  Something extraordinary Billy McKenzie is the greatest gt Scotland has given pop music. This is not up for debate. Really, only Elizabeth Fraser comes close to him. McKenzie sang like a fallen angel. Some people didnrsquot like it. Those people were wrong.The three albums he made with Alan Rankine at the turn of the s rf on Bowiersquos example to produce music that was thrillingly alien. MacKenzies career following the high point of Sulk and its attendant hit singles Party Fears Two and Club Country, was a matter ofonlys and  starts and in  he took his own le. Scottish poprsquos lost boy. But even on his misfiring  album Perhaps he could sing a line like ldquoI had a wild affair, it never lasted and inject a novelrsquos worth of feeling into just a few words.Best for: Anyone who wants to know what the best Scottish pop can aspire to.Avoid : You dont like singing that breaks with Ed Sheeran middling-ness.MARMALADELong before the Eagles and Jackson Browne there was Marmalade, who sounded as though theyrsquod grown up on the San Andreas fault and were weaned on tequila rather than fortied wine. Originally The Gaylords , the band produced lovely swish harmonies, revealed on the likes of Cousin Norman and even Ob-La-Di-ob-lad-da but just as importantly they sang out loud you could be Scottish and not sound like Jimmy Shand.Best For: Classics such as Reflections Of My Le.Avoid : Yoursquore not keen on the Beatles reggae back catalogue.ALTERED IMAGESPost-punk-new-wave-turned-mainstream pop outfit Altered Images was fronted by the very cool Clare Grogan, famous, of course, for the film Gregoryrsquos Girl in which she played heavy-fringed, sweet-voiced Susan, apple of Gregoryrsquos eye . They were far from a flash in the pan, with six UK top  hit singles Best for: Infuriatingly catchy pop.Avoid : Infuriatingly catchy pop makes you vomit.PRIMAL SCREAMIf they had written nothing after Screamadelica, which remains perfect almost  years one, the would still get my vote. To run the country. Did you see Bobby Gillespie on This Week They lived as rock stars are supposed to, which is to say they lived well but unwisely, and yet continued to churn out dance and rock classics all done with swagger, style and utter distain for just about anyone .XTRMNTR, released in , is one of the great British albums of the millennium. With songs called Swastika Eyes and Kill All Hippies, whatrsquos not to like. As a live act, few can touch them.Best for: People who like honestyAvoid : You canrsquot forgive any band for ripping off rfsHUE AND CRYThe brothers Kane did their very best to convince the world they were Scotlandrsquos answer to Daryl Hall and John Oates back in the s with their powerful Stars Crash Down album. Clutches of singles such as Looking For Linda and Remote revealed the duo from Coatbridge could write haunting, hooky melodies butthere was a glitch in their armour it was they seemed to leap all too easily over the genres, which made them harder to sell.Best For: Strong melodies and Pat Kanersquos voice, which was close to being that of a classy crooner.Avoid : You like your bands to enjoy being pop stars.JOSEF KBlazing a trail for Scottish post-punk bands in the early s were Edinburghrsquos super-cool Josef K, named for a character in Franz Kafkarsquos The Trial, fronted by the charismatic Paul Haig and driven by a lo-fi sound that blended nervy, intense guitars with a propulsive rhythm section. At their best in a live setting, they only released one album ndash rsquos The Only Fun In Town, on Postcard Records ndash but somehow that has only burnished their glistening reputation. Along with fellow Edinburgh scenesters The Fire Engines, they remain one of Scotlandrsquos most iconic bands.Best for: Refuting the argument that the only good band to come out of Edinburgh were the Rollers.Avoid : You think Steely Dan should have spent a bit more time on their studio production.SIMPLE MINDSEyeliner, goose stepping and songs which featured a single chord were all emblematic of Simple Minds early work, and in fact little changed over the years.The Minds assumed the arrival of dance, in that they appreciated how far rock fans could travel without a chorus, and certainly never imaged a middle eight would in any way improve a song. The likes of Waterfront, however, proved so intoxicating that Jim Kerr still manages to sell us it today.Best For: Loud, hypnotic melodies.Avoid : Yoursquore trying to avoid the pop star intrusion into polemics.FRUITS OF PASSIONItrsquos a darn disgrace that Fruits of Passion didnrsquot reach the heady heights of pop stardom in, say, the same way that Texas and Deacon Blue did around the same time. Their five singles, released in the mid-s and collected together on their one and only self-titled album, are perfectly crafted pop classics. Vocalist Sharon Dunleavy was an s goddess, all spiky hair and giant earrings, soaring vocals with added heartbreak, and me and my teenage friends LOVED her for it.Best for: Joyful s pop fans.Avoid : Pop doesnrsquot bring you joy.BELLE AND SEBASTIANThe missing link between Glasgow faves The Pastels and every indie outfit to have come out of the cityrsquos art school since about , Belle And Sebastian can lay claim to also being one of Scotlandrsquos most Marmite-y bands: some hate them, many others adore them. But whether you view main man Stuart Murdoch as a twee romantic or the lyrical heir to Edwyn Collins and Morrissey therersquos no doubting the bandrsquos staying power and the impact they have had on a generation of Scottish musicians.Best for: Getting over a break-upAvoid : Yoursquore allergic to duffel coats and s pop-inspired earworms.THE COMMUNARDSFronted by Glasgow-born tto Jimmy Somerville, The Communards only racked up three top  singles but one of them ndash Donrsquot Leave Me This Way, Somervillersquos Hi-NRG take on Thelma Houstonrsquos disco take on the Harold Melvin And The Bluenotes soul classic ndash hit the top spot in , and both Communards albums went platinum. But more than that, as out gay men both Somerville and bandmate Richard Coles made the personal political during some of the bleakest years for the UKrsquos gay community:  ballad For A Friend was one of the first pop songs to deal with AIDs and it wasnrsquot just Donrsquot Leave Me This Wayrsquos soaring hook that made it so anthemic.Best for: Family weddings, about ten minutes before last orders and just ahead of Come On Eileen.Avoid : You prefer your singers to be at the Barry White end of the vocal range.Top : Scotlands all-time favourite albumsWET WET WETClydebankrsquos superstars appeared at the end of the s claiming to be a musical collective but the reality was that hits such as Goodnight Girl and Sweet Little Mystery were written by Graeme Clark. What the band also had was the enigmatic Marti Pellow, with the broadest smile in pop hiding some of the deepest unhappiness. Part of that unhappiness emerged from the fact the band never appeared to be as cool as theyrsquod loved to have been. Pop  Soul  Who knows.Best For: Saturday night party songs.Avoid If: You hate Love Is All Around. Marti certainly did.THE BIG DISHThis band, which formed in Airdrie around , had a knack of creating albums absolutely jam-packed full of brilliant songs. From the critically acclaimed Swimmer to the happy, more poppy Creeping Up on Jesus, you always knew you could stick a Big Dish cassette in the car radio and never have to waste hours trying to fast-forward and rewind it to the good bits.Best for: Fans of polished pop.Avoid : You much prefer ex-frontman Steven Lindsayrsquos solo stuff.THE SUPERNATURALSOne of the best things about Scotlandrsquos music scene in  is that The Supernaturals ndash cheerful Monkees-meets-the Boo Radleys popmasters of the late nineties and early noughties ndash are part of it. The band, most famous for its hit Smile, which has been used in adverts aplenty, are back and thatrsquos great news for the legions of fans who supported them through three brilliant albums, extensive tours and an Ivor Novello award nomination. Top band to see live.Best for: Witty lyrics and catchy tunes.Avoid : You think chirpy s indie pop bands who have broken up should stay broken up.STEALERS WHEELAlas, Stealers Wheel, you were gone too soon. The self-titled debut album included Stuck in the Middle With You as "the single you thought was the best Dylan record since " the  follow-up, Ferguslie Park, is a classic:  songs by Gerry Rafferty and Joe Egan, replete with gorgeous melodies and harmonies: Good Businessman, Star, Over My Head, Nothings Gonna Change My Mind, Steamboat Row. The last album, s Right or Wrong, remains under-rated, even today. Rafferty would of course have a splendid solo career, but his and Egans songs in Stealers Wheel - Ferguslie Park in particular - are worth visiting or re-visiting.Best For: Fans of high-quality songwriting and or intrigued to hear what a British version of Crosby Stills Nash  Young might have sounded like.Avoid If: Youre not a fan of high-quality songwriting and or are not intrigued to hear what a British version of CSNY might have sounded like.DEACON BLUEHave you ever been to a party in which no one, towards the end of the night, has sang Dignity  No. This has never taken place in Scotland since Raintown was released in  and will continue to the end of time as we know it. Ricky Rossrsquos hit rate however has revealed himself to be a master muso and a very clever lyricist. And Lorraine McIntoshrsquos harmonies are not to be dismissed.Best For: Whooping and hollering along to the likes of Real Gone Kid.Avoid : You donrsquot remember all the words to Dignity.LLOYD COLE AND THE COMMOTIONSFormed around a group of Glasgow University friends, one of whom was the titular Mr Cole, The Commotions were pretentious to a tee which is why they can lay claim to being the only Scottish band to name-check Eva Marie Saint, Arthur Lee and Norman Mailer on the same record. But they were also the authors of the catchiest British pop song of the s, rsquos Perfect Skin, and one of the decadersquos best British albums ndash Rattlesnakes, their evergreen  debut. For that reason alone they deserve to be in the pantheon of Scottish greats.Best for: Moody cover versions ndash check out Tori Amosrsquos haunting take on the Rattlesnakes title track.Avoid : Right now yoursquore going ldquoEva Marie Who "THE AVERAGE WHITE BANDThere arenrsquot many Dundee bands who have signed to Atlantic, moved to LA and topped the US album charts with a funk and soul record in the same year as Curtis Mayfield, Al Green and Bobby Womack all had albums out . But The Average White Band did all that and more ndash the more including being sampled by hip-hop acts like Beasties Boys and A Tribe Called Quest, and laying down one of the sharpest instrumental tracks of all time: Pick Up The Pieces, three minutes  seconds of stone cold funk magic.Best for: Keeping on and on until the break of dawn.Avoid : Dundonian funk doesnrsquot rock your boat.Paul Buchanan on Scotlands favourite album, HatsACDCForget Scotland or Australia, they are simply the greatest rock n roll band theres ever been with a back catalogue that will blow up anyones stereo. Brothers Malcolm, Angus, and George Young were born in Glasgow while original front man Bon Scott was born in Forfar. A le-sized statue of Scott has pride of place in Kirriemuir where the annual BonFest take place and  years ago a Scottish Parliament motion was filed ember calling for the achievements of AC DC to be acknowledged. We should salute them.Best for: Anyone who freaks to the sound of a electric guitar played by a dementor.Avoid : You love ballads and loathe innuendo.COCTEAU TWINSIf you had to pick the one artist or band who sounded like they came from a dferent galaxy it would probably be this Grangemouth combo who put the dream in dream pop and produced one of the greatest voices in the form of Elizabeth Fraser. As with all the best music you may not have known what it was when you first heard them. It sounded like music for druggies.Best for: Everyone.Avoid : You think singing in an indecipherable language is utterly pretentious.YOUNG FATHERSExquisitely crafted and experimental art pop hip hop fashioned in Edinburgh that embraces the world and is as multi-cultural sounding as Alloysious Massaquoi, Kayus Bankole and Graham G Hastings are as iniduals.Best for: Those who enjoy music that challenges them.Avoid : You dont enjoy music that challenges you.DJANGO DJANGOFrom the bedroom-produced joys of their eponymous Mercury Prize nominated  debut, to the classic synth-based pop of their third album Marble Skies, this sublimely eclectic four-piece Edinburgh-formed avant-pop combo are a surfabilly thrill ride. Exuberant harmonies and killer synth hooks are the order of the day and they show no signs of letting up.Best for: Getting you from the bar to the dancefloor.Avoid : You dont want to get from the bar to the dancefloor.RUNRIGThey transcended the Scottish Celtic rock scene with tracks such as Hearthammer, Rhythm Of My Heart and An Ubhal As Airdendash the first and only Scottish Gaelic language song to reach the UK Top .The band, formed on Skye in , has seen copious line-ups over the years but for many fans the distinctive voice of lead singer Donnie Munro alongside songwriting brothers Rory and Calum Macdonald are perhaps most synonymous with the sound of Runrig.I would defy anyone not to get a tingle down the spine at hearing the live version of The Bonnie Banks o Loch Lomond as played at Balloch on June , .Best for: Pounding rhythms and rousing lyrics.Avoid : You lack a poeticrsquos soul.IDLEWILDIf you wanted to experience a manic pop thrill play Film For The Future by Roddy Woomble and co from their still irresistible debut album Hope Is Important.Best for: Inducing a headrush of guitar-induced sonic powerlistening to Captain, Hope is Important and some of The Remote Part.Avoid : Driving a car .ORANGE JUICEldquoI wear my fringe like Roger McGuinnrsquos hellip Come on, when did Ricky Ross ever write a line as good as that  In his heyday Edwyn Collins had more fun being a pop star than anyone  born north of the border. From the beginning Orange Juice were fey and wilful and arrogant, slightly incompetentand full of eff-you snottiness, which is exactly what you want in your pop stars. Maybe Edwyn was too cool for school to write anything that aches the way Roddy Framersquos We Could Send Letters aches, but, man, Falling and Laughing comes close, doesnrsquot it Best for: Jangly guitars. They wrote the book on them.Avoid : You dont like jangly guitars.CAMERA OBSCURAldquoYou say your le will be the death of youTell me, do you wash your hair in honeydewAnd long for all of them to fall in love with youBut they never do.Another in a long line of smart, pop-literate Scottish bands elevated above their peers by the fact that Traceyanne Campbell could sing the UKIP manesto and it would sound great .The tragic death of band member Carey Lander seemed to have marked the end of the band, but Campbell tweeted last month that they are back rehearsing.Best for: Lovelorn music fans who find Belle and Sebastian a bit too Walter Softy for their tastes.Avoid : you need music thats injected with an excess of testosterone.BOARDS OF CANADAThe Edinburgh post-electro maestros Dayvan Cowboy was a regular feature on the late lamented early-hours-in-the morning  Minutes show on MTV that was devoted to leftfield music. But it wasnt until the stunning Music has The Right To Children album that the penny dropped and when it did the almost orchestral wonders of Michael Sandison and Marcus Eoins downtempo ambient structures and form made sense.Best for: Chilling.Avoid : Not chilling.MOGWAIStuart Braithwaites crew pretty much define the term post rock and can mess with your headnot in the right mood. Listen to the incredible peaks-and-troughs soft-loud non-album track called My Father, My King ndash a -minute long entry point which was for a long time the best thing they had done. When your ears get attuned to their sonic power, the sheer intensity and dynamic melodies become a real rush.Best for: Giving your unided attention.Avoid : Loud guitars make your scared.BLANCK MASSThe drone electro project from Edinburghs Benjamin John Power, one of the founding members of F*** Buttons is one of the most exciting to emerge in this decade. His art is in his single-minded experimentation which revealed itself in his Odd Scene EP, the title track being a never-to-be repeated mash of electro drone, hardcore punk, black metal and goth that would make Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails weep.Best for: Lovers of in-yer-face electronicsAvoid : You find loud synths scary.THE KLFLook, anyone who could get Tammy Wynette to sing ldquoTheyrsquore justied and theyrsquore ancient. And they drive an ice cream van, gets our vote. In their time Bill Drummondand Jimmy Cauty burned poundmillion on a Scottish beach, took the Doctor Who theme tune to number oneand made some of the greatest Acid House anthems of the age. They bowed out at the Brits in  when they duetted with Extreme Noise Terror, and Drummond fired blanks from an automatic weapon at the audience. The KLF always knew the value of theatre.Best for: Going ldquoWooh wooh along with the band every time What Time is Love  Comes on the radio.Avoid : You have no sense of humour. Or two left feet.THE TRASHCAN SINATRASTheir timing was always lousy. Too late for Postcard, too early for the Postcard revival, constantly out of step with the zeitgeistAll that left is a series of albums so casually bruised and gorgeous that listening to them you canrsquot work how something that sounds so simple can break your heart so easily. If you want proof play Weightlting on repeat. It would make a great national anthem, by the way.Best For: Beta-male boys and girls who know that le is hard but sometimes beautul.Avoid : You are allergic to harmonies.What no Bay City Rollers or Hipsway, Gun or Franz Ferdinand  Tell us who weve missed off the list and why at letters@theherald.Compiled by Teddy Jamieson, Susan Swarbrick, Vicky Allan, Martin Williams, Barry Didcock, Russell Leadbetter, Marianne Taylor, Drew Allan, Andy Clark, Brian Beacom, Scott Wright, Neil Cameron, Ann Fotheringham, Garry Scott, and Mark Smith

title: scotland-would-be-biggest-loser-from-abolition-of-erasmus-scheme-after-brexit
story: More students north of the Border choose to study and train in the EU through the Erasmus scheme than in nine other areas of the UK.The Erasmus programme, which was set up in , allows students to study or acquire skills in another EU country.The Prime Ministerrsquos Chequers agreement promised to ldquoexplore participation in the scheme, but it was not mentioned in the political declaration on the future relationship with the EU that May negotiated.Around , students from the UK take part every year, of which , study abroad, and Brexit has placed a question mark over whether the scheme will continue.It was revealed last week that students currently on the programme are in the dark over funding and accommodation, and some iniduals fear they could be left without health insurance.Figures released by the Peoplersquos Vote campaign, which backs another referendum, break down the the number of UK Erasmus students by  areas. The statistics, which are based on yearly averages covering  to , show that , students from Scottish universities participated in the scheme during this period.In second place was London, with ,, followed by the South West on , and , for the South East.Universities such as Edinburgh, Exeter, Leeds, Durham, Nottingham, and Bristol would be among the biggest losers.Popular destinations include France, Spain, Germany, and Italy.David Rodger, , who is originally from Stonehaven, studied French and German at St Andrews University, and spent a year in Leipzig.Back at St Andrews, he met his girlfriend Andrea, a Spanish student on an Erasmus year at the Fe university.ldquoIrsquove always loved languages and therersquos no better way to learn one than fully immersing yourself in a new city and culture. Erasmus offers kids from Scotland a brilliant opportunity to live and study at top Universities across the continent, he said.Richard Lochhead, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Further Education Minister, said: ldquoBrexit poses a direct threat to our membership of Erasmus, particularly in the event of a no deal.

title: independence-activist-promises-never-to-vote-snp-again-over-sturgeon-picture
story: Jonathon Shafi, who was a senior figure in the Radical Independence campaign, said it was ldquoabsolutely sickening to see Sturgeon photographed with Alastair Campbell, who worked for the former Labour Prime Minister during the run up to the Iraq war.Sturgeon was one of the high profile political figures at an anti-Brexit rally in London yesterday, at which campaigners called for Article  to be revoked and a second referendum to be held.The huge show of support for the UKrsquos place in the EU attracted cross-party support, with politicians such as London Mayor Sadiq Khan, Lib Dem leader Vince Cable and deputy Labour leader Tom Watson joining Sturgeon.Ahead of the rally starting, former Labour MP Douglas Alexander appeared to have a dig at the SNP by saying he was attending for his friend Blair McDougall, who led the pro-UK Better Together campaign: ldquoAnd everyone like him, near and far, who opposes nationalism  isolationism.Campbell, who was Blairrsquos spin doctor in opposition and then took on a similar role in Downing Street, was also on the march and a photograph of himself with Sturgeon was posted on his Instagram accountCampbell wrote: ldquoSorry Douglas. Sorry Ian. But I am genuinely pleased @nicolasturgeon is here to to speak for @peoples_vote.Shafi, who co-founded the RIC, responded: ldquoIrsquom done. Irsquom f***ing done.He wrote: ldquoAlistair Campbell is responsible for opening the gates of hell to millions of Iraqis. Sturgeon happy to pose with him. Proud even. Totally done. The SNP will never, ever, get my vote again as long as she is leader.Alistair Campbell is responsible for opening the gates of hell to millions of Iraqis. Sturgeon happy to pose with him. Proud even. Totally done. The SNP will never, ever, get my vote again as long as she is leader.After being challenged by a former SNP MSP, Shafi wrote: ldquoI dont cuddle up to people who led is [sic] to a war that destroyed the lives of millions. Your leader does.He added: ldquoThis is personal too. I made a promise when they bombed Iraq that I would never forget. That I would committ to a le of trying to ensure such a thing would never happen again. That those responsible would be held accountable. Sorry @NicolaSturgeon but a line has been crossed.

title: richard-leonard-urges-swifter-action-to-tackle-child-poverty
story: In the wake of a report forecasting child poverty in Scotland will hit a -year high, the Scottish party leader has written to Ms Sturgeon to call for action.Mr Leonard has asked the First Minister to either introduce an income supplement sooner than a planned start date of  or increase child benefit by pound per week.ldquoIt is my view that the poorest families in Scotland cannot afford to wait any longer, he wrote.ldquoI am writing to you today to ask that you bring forward plans for an income supplement as a matter of urgency.ldquoIt should be in your next programme for government and in the next Scottish budget.ldquoIf you believe that the Government is not capable of bringing forward these proposals in the next  months then I would urge the Government to increase child benefit by pound per week.Studies into child poverty released this week highlighted the expected rise in the number of children living below the poverty line.Research by the Resolution Foundation warned that an extra , children risk being plunged into poverty by -, almost a third of all Scottish children.The think tank warned thatthe Scottish Government does not take radical action, it will miss its own child poverty target of reducing relative poverty to below % by -, equivalent to more than , children.While UK-wide benefit policies are blamed for driving up poverty in Scotland and the rest of the UK, the Scottish Government ldquohas not announced plans remotely large enough to counteract that rise, the Foundation claimed.Scottish Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell said: ldquoThis report is a stark reminder of the challenges we face to end child poverty in Scotland.ldquoWe are tackling child poverty with one hand behind our back in the face of the devastating impact of the UK Governmentrsquos welfare cuts and benefits freeze which are set to push thousands more of the poorest and most vulnerable families into poverty.ldquoWe are doing all we can with the powers we have to mitigate those cuts, protect people on low incomes, and secure our ambitions to eradicate child poverty and have a range of actions and a multi-million pound package of investment to deliver on that.Another report, released by the Equality and Human Rights Commission Scotland, forecasts a further , children will be pushed into poverty by .Referencing the study, Mr Leonard added: ldquoIt would be wrong to walk by on the other side while an additional , children grow up in poverty.A Scottish Government spokesman said:ldquoTopping up child benefit will not deliver the greatest impact for the families who need it most.ldquoThat is why we are working towards a new income supplement, to provide additional financial support to low income families.ldquoWe have been working closely with stakeholders to look at all options for that, guided by two key principles ndash reaching the greatest number of children in poverty, and ensuring we top up incomes sufficiently to lt those households out of poverty. We will provide an update on this work in June.

title: vigils-across-scotland-call-for-peace-and-religious-tolerance
story: In an event organised by the Muslim Council of Scotland on Saturday, religious leaders joined with politicians, campaigners and members of the public in solidarity in the face of intolerance.At a vigil held on Glasgowrsquos George Square, speakers included Justice Secretary Humza Yousaf, SNP MP Alison Thewliss, Lord Provost Eva Bolander, Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard, Labour MSP Anas Sarwar and human rights lawyer Aamer Anwar.In his speech, Mr Yousaf said that politicians and the media must help play a role in tackling intolerance in society.ldquoThat attack didnrsquot happen in a vacuum, Mr Yousaf said. ldquoThe political discourse, the media discourse on Islam, on Muslims, on minorities is adding a gallon of petrol on a fire that does not need to be there.ldquoSo when Boris Johnson says that women in niqab look like bankrobbers, or letterboxes ndash Boris Johnson, shame on you because yoursquore the one thatrsquos adding fuel to the fire.ldquoWhen politicians talk about swarms of immigrants, talk about villages and towns being swamped by immigrants, then you are part of the problem.ldquoWhen we have our media outlets ndash not all of the them, many of them good ndash but when we have some of our media outlets that will give s to the hate-mongers like Tommy Robinson or invite Nigel Farage who makes issues around immigration his central core, using inflammatory language, when they give him more time on Question Time than the SNP, the Liberal Democrats, Labour put together, then Irsquom sorry, therersquos a problem with our media outlets.Scottish Labour MSP Anas Sarwar urged all people from dferent backgrounds to work together to root out all forms all hate and intolerance.ldquoI say to you all, please do not think this is someone rsquos fight ndash this is your fight as well, said Mr Sarwar.ldquoDo not leave the fight against Islamophobia to the Muslim community, itrsquos a fight for all of us.ldquoDonrsquot leave the fight against anti-Semitism to the Jewish community, itrsquos a fight for all of us.ldquoDonrsquot leave the fight against racism to our erse minority-ethnic communities, itrsquos a fight for all of us.ldquoAnd also to the brothers in the room, donrsquot leave the fight against sexism to the sisters, itrsquos a fight for all of us.ldquoOnlywe see it as our own fight, onlywe build allies, onlywe stand title: joanna-blythman-reviews-stravaigin-glasgow
story: We find ourselves here in the bar, by accident rather than intention. On an otherwise somnolent Tuesday lunch time its really welcoming: chilled, but not dead. It feels lived in, well curated, timeless: zinc-topped bar, old church chairs, skew-whf glass lampshades, coppiced branches laced with twinkling lights, aged, sturdy tobacco brown wood ling and reclaimed planks brightened by hints of arsenic green paint. Staff behave like people who are happy at work.: Pasha, North Frederick Street, Glasgow. Restaurant review by Ron MackennaNominally a ldquoside dish at a mere pound., this intelligently composed winter salad of bitter chicory, peppery rocket, and walnuts that taste freshly toasted, all tossed in a Stilton vinaigrette, is just what I fancy. We marvel at the ldquosmall plate of mussels. Its pound. tag is deceptive. Itrsquos enough for lunch, an ample bowlful of bivalves, plump, fleshy specimens, in a thick Asian soup thatrsquos not for wimps, a thicker version of Indian rasam, aromatic with lime leaf, cinnamon bark, cloves, star anise, and just a hint of sweetness to round it off. Therersquos also a blisteringly hot flatbread to dunk into it. It tears away in circular strands, a bit like a Malaysian roti cenai. Heaps of effort is packed into this dish, yet itrsquos inexpensive.Hake, a special on todayrsquos menu, is a pleasure to behold, a steak cut from the centre of a well-proportioned specimen impeccably grilled under its cape of green herbs. Wild garlic scent wafts up from the plate. It twines around roasted slices of purple potato, which have that rewarding, elusive flavour and floury texture thatrsquos now such a rarity because these characteristics have been bred out of modern ldquomultipurpose commercial potato ieties. Squash pureacutee adds a brightening dash of orange to the opalescence of the fish, setting off the emerald garlic leaves, and the muted imperial purple of the potatoes.The fishcake is also made with hake, and once again, we taste Stravaiginrsquos very evident proficiency with the use of spice. Its innards have the hue of brown crab meat, I guess from a fresh-made curry paste, which lends sharp backbone, perhaps from tomato, with the earthy undertow of turmeric. The necessary oiliness of its breadcrumb jacket is offset by juicy ribs of crunchy, refreshing pak choi that have had a fleeting visit to a searingly hot wok. A runny-yolked poached egg, and satiny, coriander-speckled Hollandaise layer, add wanton enrichment to the already satisfying fish.We catch up with the plum frangipane tart in a just-out-the-oven state. Its thick, yet barely cooked centre, rather like liquid marzipan with opulent dark plums bleeding into it, is only just bound by a taut corset of gloriously buttery, almost butterscotch pastry. This paragon of patisserie perfection is partnered beautully by a scoop of toasted almond ice cream, which tastes like essence of the very best Spanish nougat. Apple and olive oil cake from the daily menu hits that bliss point between too hot to eat and freshly baked. Moist within from the oil, and subtly conveying all the grassy, green flavours in it, it really does taste ine. The exterior is an up hill and down dale landscape of biscuity crust and apple chunks. Translucent pools of sharp, punchy green apple compote, and amber caramel, accentuate the winning sweet-sourness of the cake, while lemony cregraveme fraiche ice cream decisively nudges this dessert away from excessive cloyingness.In its own words, Stravaigin has been ldquowandering since  and ldquoshowcasing Scottish produce that isnrsquot tethered to its roots. Despite all those fawning write-ups that might encourage smugness, it doesnrsquot put a foot wrong.Stravaigin,  Gibson Street, Glasgow   Food:  Atmosphere:  Value for money:  Service

title: iain-macwhirter-to-stop-mays-thelma-and-louise-dash-for-the-no-deal-cliff-edge-mps-must-now-take-back-control
story: I donrsquot want to go back to anger and denial. Wersquove had enough of that from Theresa May. The can has been kicked down the road so often that you just want to jump on it and flatten the damned thing.This week we go back to the bargaining stage, but we may not even get that. Parliament has been given an extra fortnight for May to preicate, and for the Commons to avoid coming to a consensus.At least the prospect of no deal on Friday might have concentrated minds, like an execution, and forced MPs to seize the reins of power from this battered and friendless Prime Minister.Instead, we have another fortnight to learn what we already know: that MV seems as remote as ever, and Theresa May wonrsquot give up on it.The European Unionrsquos political leaders were, of course, acting in their own best interests on Thursday. Having listened to May ramble on incoherently for  minutes, the  concluded that, yes, she really is daft enough to let a no-deal Brexit happen.Well, they can live with thatthey have to. But what they werenrsquot prepared to do is allow her to blame the European Union for the breakdown so, to coin a phrase, they took back control.The heads of government offered to delay the Brexit deadline until May ,she gets her deal through Parliament, or April she doesnrsquot. They will go the extra mile, explore all options, and then even offer a longer extensionall  fails. Itrsquos jaw-jaw not war-war, and they are the virtuosos of jaw-jaw.Though in truth, Brussels doesnrsquot really know what happens when the talking finally ends.The problem with the European Union is that they expect political leaders to behave as rational agents, who seek the most advantageous outcome. They donrsquot have protocols to deal with mad-as-a-hatter prime ministers and a parliament that has lost the plot.The UK has decided to have a collective mental breakdown, in full technicolour, and will not be talked out of it by boring bureaucrats with their seemingly sensible solutions.After , days, the simple fact is that UK still doesnrsquot know what Brexit means. That image of the cat manically scratching at the door, and then refusing to leave when itrsquos opened, is only too apt.Everyone knows that the obvious destination for a country like Britain, which has vital trading links with Europe but doesnrsquot want to be part of the political union, is to join the European Economic Area, now dubbed ldquoCommon Market ..That alone allows friction-free trade, avoids an Irish border and halts these daft, wartime preparations for no deal. .There has always been a majority in Parliament for soft Brexit, everyone says so. But as I pointed out last week, our system seems incapable of distilling compromise from the mash of party interests.MPs say they want to reach across party boundaries, but as last weekrsquos walkouts and tetchy letters confirmed, they donrsquot really. No-one wants to take any responsibility, no one wants to blink first, no-one wants to make the first step.Yet to halt Theresa Mayrsquos Thelma and Louise-style drive to the clf edge, ministers and MPs will have to remove her from office, probably through a confidence motion, and set up a kind of provisional government.They need to force the long delay she refuses to contemplate. This weekrsquos indicative votes on their own wonrsquot cut it. The nightmare, indeed, is that nothing gets a majority.The Westminster system requires a semi-dictatorial Prime Minister, with an unassailable majority, to . But May is a dictator without an army. She has no majority, yet perversely behaves asshe still has one.What residue of authority she possessed evaporated after her petulant outburst against MPs on Wednesday. Even Labour MPs who were tempted to vote for her deal, like Lisa Nandy, were so outraged that they resolved to vote against her come what may.What can you do with a Prime Minister who wilfully alienates her potential allies Theresa May actually had a point about Parliament only being able to agree on what it doesnrsquot want. We all thought that the problem was the Withdrawal Agreement, the -page legal document signed off by May last year, which contained the infamous Irish backstop. But we now know that this is not the case.Last week, Labour declared that they did not have any problems with the Withdrawal Agreement or the backstop, despite Jeremy Corbyn having condemned it in November. He said then that Mayrsquos Withdrawal Agreement was ldquoa half-baked deal which Britain cannot leave, and the backstop would deny Britain ldquothe sovereign right of any UK parliament to unilaterally withdraw from any backstop.All Labour now wants is a tweak to the Political Declaration ndash that non-binding, non-legal compendium of cliches, aspiration and wishful thinking that accompanied the Withdrawal Agreement. I seem to remember writing that to say this was woolly would be an insult to sheep. So why has it become a deal-breaker The blame obviously lies principally with the Prime Minister ndash a woman so bereft of vision and leadership ability that she shouldnrsquot be left in charge of a milk float, let alone a country.She could have offered Labour anything they wanted: full consultation, customs union, workers rights, environmental standards, regulatory alignment. It would have meant little because the Political Declaration is non-binding. Instead, she has made a fetish of inflexibility which is the worst failing in a political leader. She is in love with her idea of herself as a ldquobloody dficult woman, and thinks that backing down, resiling, is a betrayal of her sex.That is why I ended up voting for the petition to Revoke Article . To my horror, I found myself agreeing with Nigel Farage and Michael Portillo that the only real choice,Parliament cannot act, is between no deal and no Brexit.The only certain way to end this horror show is to pull the plug, halt the madness and pretend the last three years never happened. EvenParliament does end up backing Mayrsquos deal, which of course is still possible, it wonrsquot put an end to this nightmare.The Withdrawal Agreement is only the start. It deals with citizenship, the orce bill and the Irish backstop. Negotiations over Britainrsquos future trading relations with the EU have yet to begin, and will take two to four years. Four more years of this would be beyond endurance.And it wonrsquot be Theresa May who is doing the negotiating, but perhaps Boris Johnson, or some other Tory leader. If voters were fully aware of this fact, Irsquom sure that the parliamentary petition calling for Article  to be revoked would top  million within the week.

title: how-orkney-reinvented-the-future-with-hydrogen
story: ldquoIn , it said, ldquoOrkney was the first to generate hydrogen from tidal power, using electricity to split water into hydrogen and oxygen. Actor, environmentalist and hydrogen-advocate Leonardo DiCaprio shared that video on Instagram. It has been viewed , times. The world had its eyes on little Orkney as a possible beacon of low-carbon hope.It is not the first time Orkney has been there first or best. Back in , the first grid-connected wind turbine was erected in buffeting gales at Costa Head. In , a giant experimental concrete turbine, the largest of its kind, was inaugurated on Burgar Hill. Orkney was where, in , the European Marine Energy Centreinstalled Scotlandrsquos first grid-connected tidal device, and last year, a flagship tidal energy turbine generated more electricity in its first year than the whole of Scotlandrsquos wave and tidal sector produced before it.The carbon intensity of the electricity that Orkney generates and feeds into the main grid is almost the lowest anywhere in the world, at just g CO kWh. Only El Hierro, in the Canary Islands, beats it.Hydrogen is Orkneyrsquos latest possible game-changer. New projects on the islands are fitting ferries to run on the gas, which is produced from local renewables.Hydrogen boiler heating systems are being fitted into a primary school. Orkney Islands Council, a signicant force in the developments, is running a fleet of hydrogen-fuelled vans.A key player in these changes is the wave and tidal test and research centre, EMEC. Its hydrogen manager Jon Clipsham says that a favourite phrase at the centre is ldquothe art of the possible.ldquoWith these projects wersquove proved itrsquos possible, he says. ldquoIt also has to happen. If it doesnrsquot wersquove got nothing to hand over to the next generations, because Irsquom more than of the opinion that the climate is changing, and quite rapidly now.What is it about these islands  Partly, of course, itrsquos the climate and location itself ndash the rapid tidal currents that run through its sounds, the constant winds. Itrsquos also that for decades it struggled with the fact that it is an island, connected to the mainland electricity by an undersea cable, and suffers the worst fuel poverty in the UK ndash partially caused by being off the gas grid and stuck with one of the highest rates for grid electricity.Hydrogen technology has developed in Orkney, in part, because the islands had a problem.This archipelago with its now more than  wind turbines and developing tidal renewables was generating too much electricity for its own needs ndash it now produces the equivalent of % of its electricity demand ndash and wasnrsquot able to send more down the line to the grid.The cable connecting to the mainland could only carry a small fraction of what it was generating.Communities had erected wind turbines but were not seeing the expected revenue s, and were having their generation curtailed, some to just % of what they could generate. So great is the problem that currently there is a moratorium on further wind development.Clipsham says: ldquoThe huge expansion in renewable energy led to a point where there was more energy being produced than we could feed back through the cable to the mainland. That meant those who had invested in wind technologies were unable to get the revenue they were looking for.This was particularly frustrating, says Clipsham, because the sheer abundance of natural wind and tide resource on the islands meant ldquoyou could deploy  times, possibly more, of it than what wersquove currently deployed.Community groups had bought in to the idea of using the feed-in tarfs as a means of generating revenue for projects and services but werenrsquot seeing the expected payback. A further issue is that while Orkney is host to incredible renewables potential, the communities also suffer the worst fuel poverty in the UK. A factor in this is that there is no gas grid on Orkney and the electrical supply can cost as much as p per kWh, making it among the highest in the UK.The Orkney community was looking to find answers to these problems and, around seven years ago, EMEC began to look at using the renewables technology to make hydrogen by electrolysis. ldquoEMEC has always been very future-focused, says Jon Clipsham, ldquoand hydrogen is not new. Itrsquos been around for a long, long time. Iceland had a boom-and-bust cycle. But we began to look at it.ldquoThoughts of how we need to decarbonise the world were very present. By  , things had really some momentum and we decided to go for hydrogen.The first project was Surf rsquonrsquo Turf, a wind and tidal energy project that was all about grid balancing, in which energy was harvested when it couldnrsquot be put into the grid, stored, and regenerated as electricity when there was the opportunity to export it.However, it was quickly recognised that the hydrogen could also be used as a fuel. ldquoThe premise, says Clipsham, ldquoshted from grid balancing to setting us off on the journey which we are now well advanced with, towards having a fledged hydrogen economy.As part of EMECrsquos European Union and Scottish Government-funded Big Hit project, hydrogen heating boilers are being fitted in a school on the Orkney island of Shapinsay. Meanwhile, a car ferry is under construction which will run on hydrogen, and this year will see the installation of a hydrogen system into one of the ferries currently running between Shapinsay and Kirkwall.Such technological development seems timely. In December last year, Maersk, the worldrsquos largest container shipping company, announced it aimed to be carbon neutral by  ndash currently it is looking at biofuels.Clipsham is interested in how these hydrogen and renewables technologies might scale up or be adapted in dferent locations. ldquoCan the learnings we got here be transitioned  Yes. Energy systems are becoming increasingly decentralised, so yoursquore breaking things down into smaller chunks, so you might see some of the knowledge wersquove gained on Orkney rolled out and used on a block of flats, or a housing estate or a leisure centre.There is a sense on the island right now that what they are doing is being watched. Steven Bews, a builder who grew up on Shapinsay where the Big Hit project is based, is, as chair of Shapinsay Development Trust, involved in his community turbinersquos integration in the project. ldquoWe do feel a wee bit like the whole world is looking at us, he says. ldquoI keep seeing it on social media. Orkney and the Big Hit project is being highlighted and itrsquos good to see that the wider world is aware of us.For Bews, the idea that he is getting to be part of a greener future is as important as the local benefits. ldquoTherersquos a feeling that you are being environmentally friendly in what yoursquore doing. Yoursquore trying to lever the whole industry away from carbon and on to renewable green energy ndash and while it is in its infancy, I believe hydrogen has the potential to eventually replace a diesel and hydrocarbon-thirsty transport infrastructure.The awareness of climate change is strong on the islands. Almost everyone has some story to tell of its impact. Adele Lidderdale, hydrogen project officer at Orkney Islands Council, observes: ldquoYou see crop failure. We had flooding over the past  years that we didnrsquot previously see. We know the impact that the environment can have on day-to-day le.Lidderdale, whose great grandfather came from Orkney, grew up on the islands. Her husband grew up on Shapinsay, where one of the key hydrogen projects is based. ldquoWhen yoursquore in such a small community you see the impact first hand. You have to answer to the community. I think thatrsquos part of the unique mixture of why wersquore able to get these things done. You know that yoursquore going to have to answer to the people who are going to be affected by any decisions you make.Part of the appeal of the Orkney hydrogen project is that it shows on a small, very human scale, how hydrogen could become part of the answer in a low-carbon future. Nigel Holmes, chief executive of the Scottish Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Association, sees great promise in what is happening on the islands.ldquoOrkney is almost like a microcosm of some of the things we are trying to tackle. We can show how we make the hydrogen from renewables, we can move it around, we can store it. We can show how it can be used in transport. We can show it can be used for making power, also for heating. The project helps people to appreciate the interconnected nature of some of these networks ndash because itrsquos all there in one place.Clipsham has watched the project develop and believes that one of the key things about the Orkney Islands is the people. ldquoPeople are starting to ask, lsquoWhy is all this going on in the Orkney Islands  Yoursquove got , people, but theyrsquove now got a portfolio of about  million euros of hydrogen related projects happening.rsquo And thatrsquos a very good question.ldquoBut when you go to the Orkney Islands and you talk to some of them, you realise why. Because there is such a positive can-do attitude. If you give them a problem they will work out what they can do to find a solution. Andit isnrsquot obvious theyrsquoll go out and look for it. There is an absolutely amazing attitude up there.

title: si-ferry-talks-football-in-our-latest-cool-conversations
story: A le less ordinary: Partick Thistle director Jacqui Low talks politics, bereavement and smashing the glass ceilingIt helps that Ferry is a former footballer and that some of the people he interviews are just his mates, people he might chat with anyway. Just a year ago he was in the twilight days of a football career, playing for Peterhead once a week, coaching Under-s for Celtic, doing the Royal Mail night sht and sitting about the house all day. Then he got a call from some producers, who had a ldquowee idea. They found his Twitter stream funny and wonderedhe would be up for interviewing fellow footballers. Thus Open Goal was born.His shows, he says, work because they are so informal. ldquoWe donrsquot wear suits. Wersquore not good looking. Wersquove not got our hair tied back. We donrsquot use all fancy words. We always wanted to keep it like that because the thing is as soon as you start taking yourself too seriously you just end up like every other football show on the telly.The success of the show isnrsquot something he takes for granted. ldquoI think Irsquove said beforeI get paid to do anything involving football I feel quite privileged because thousands of people over the country would love to do anything involved with football and get paid for it. I had a normal job. I delivered kitchens for a bit. And I was the worst. I was terrible at it. I used to bash the kitchens up. I had no clue what to do it.Part of Open Goalrsquos secret is that the interviews reveal the struggles and some of the messiness of being a player. ldquoPeople hold these players up on a pedestal, says Ferry. ldquoThey think theyrsquove got the best lives in the world. Theyrsquove not got a care. But on interviews, yoursquoll hear they went through bad times. People like to hear that, that these guys donrsquot just live in perfect eight-room houses and drink champagne every night.Recently Open Goal triggered a bit of social media backlash when they interviewed Robbie Savage. ldquoWe had a bit of stick because hersquos down in England. Butyoursquore just going to keep it to Scottish football yoursquore going to run out. it was quite bad for a couple of nights but then when the episode went out I got a dferent they changed their opinion on him, which is why we do the show.But the April  Cool Conversation wonrsquot just be about players ndash it will be about the world of football and what happens when it meets the media and social media. Jacqui Low, one of only three women directors in the Scottish premiership and chair of Indigo PR company, will bring her years of communications experience to the discussion. Amy Irons, daughter of former footballer, Davie Irons, grew up in the world of football and now presents sport for the new BBC Scotland news show, The Nine.Book tickets at www.lateralcity events

title: dna-testing-and-bee-census-to-work-out-their-sustainability
story: The great yellow bumblebee was once common across the UK, but there are now only five known populations remaining as its habitats have gradually disappeared due to intensive farming.On the British mainland the species is only found in Caithness and north west Sutherland, with the three other colonies in Orkney and the Inner and Outer Hebrides.Until now, conservationists worried about the future of the species have been unable to tell exactly how low the populations have become, partly due to the remoteness of its remaining habitats.But a new two-year project launching next month led by the Bumblebee Conservation Trust is aiming to answer this crucial question as the first step to securing the great yellowrsquos future. Backed by funding from Scottish Natural Heritage and the Heritage Lottery Fund, the project will involve a ldquobee census and DNA testing to establish the sustainability of the remaining gene pool.The Trust said while the species was unlikely to disappear within a few years, it may have ldquojust decades left due to the tiny number of bees left in the harsh environment of the Highlands.One of  species of bumblebee in the UK, the distribution of the great yellow has declined by  per cent since , making it one of the rarest in the country.ldquoThey are very distinctive and very beautul. Therersquos nothing  really that looks like them, said Katy Malone, the Trustrsquos Scottish conservation officer, who will be leading the study.ldquoI think it should be one of those iconic species people think of when they think of the Scottish Highlands. Wildcats, red deer, red squirrels ndash and great yellow bumblebees.The number of great yellows remaining in the UK is currently unknown.She added that the species was literally ldquopushed to the edge of the UK over the decades as its preferred habitats disappeared and were replaced by farmed fields.ldquoItrsquos a specialist of open meadow habitat and flower-rich open areas, she said. ldquoThose are exactly the type of habitats that have been disappearing from our countryside, but which are still found on outlying islands and right up on the far north coast of Scotland, as the land is far less intensively managed.So far the charity has focused on helping local communities in the Highlands record great yellows in their areas and manage their habitats, but the low human populations have made this dficult.As well as counting the bees, the forthcoming study will also seek to unlock their secrets by studying what attracts them to certain habitats, so similar ones can recreated where.The charity also plans to run ldquobumblebee identication workshops to teach volunteers how to spot great yellows and encourage tourists to help with research as they explore the Highlands and Islands.

title: revealed-1370-a-month-to-live-in-squalor-in-scotlands-temporary-accommodation
story: Or a sad single room in a grotty hotel, with no cooker and no fridge, where youre not allowed to talk to anyone for fear of drug-dealing or youre locked outyoure back five minutes late at night All over the country, people are being put up in smelly, rundown private hotels and BBs due to a lack of social housing stock. And in Glasgow the taxpayer has to pay pound a week ndash thats pound a calendar month ndash for the privilege.Solicitors, charities and politicians have today called for the government to open its eyes to the scandal affecting the countryrsquos homeless population and have accused those in power of squandering taxpayers cash while keeping the most vulnerable in poverty.The director of Scotlandrsquos largest housing charity, Shelter, said the situation was due to ldquodecades of underinvestment in social housing.Residents are provided with a room, a bed, a kettle and a wardrobe. In some cases they have their own bathrooms, while in others they have to share a communal one in the corridor. In one BB, residents were forbidden from talking to each other or going to each otherrsquos rooms, while in another the doors were locked at midnight and anyone not back by then would be out for the night.Cooking facilities were rare, and in most cases residents lived on non-perishables such as instant noodles, biscuits and junk food.For the money costs to be accommodate in these places ndash pound a month ndash an "impressive drawing room conversion" is advertised for rent in the heart of Glasgows west end.The flat in an "elegant sandstone townhouse" comes with a modern kitchen, mezzanine, "stylish" two-piece bathroom and separate toilet, and is "exceptionally well-placed for local amenities and excellent transport links".And for less than that, pound a month, a two-bedroom semi-detached mews is available for rent, including council tax bills.The "elegant" property is also in the west end of Glasgow, and boasts two large bedrooms, a kitchen, bathroom and access to a garden.In Bearsden, a three-bedroom refurbished villa is on the market for just pound a month.This, they say, is only adding to or creating more problems in terms of mental health issues, addiction, isolation and unemployment.Lorna Walker, a partner at Govan Law Centre, said: ldquoThis isnt the best use of taxpayers money, when they could be putting it in to accommodation that is of a decent standard and putting it in to helping people get their lives back on track the way they want it."It is not a good way for taxpayersrsquo money to be spent at all and the authorities need to open their eyes and see that.ldquoThe law in Scotland on this issue is some of the best ndash it is very clearly written, and it is clear how it should be applied. Unfortunately, it isnrsquot working in that way.Ms Walker added that many of her clients are keen to get back to work, but as they are unable to afford to pay the extortionate pound-per-month rent and try to save for a deposit for their own homes, they are stuck in a ldquovicious cycle.She said: ldquoUnless you are on a great wage, itrsquos a lot of money to pay. Itrsquos more than most peoplersquos mortgages.ldquoPeople may be stuck there for months and sometimes years, and itrsquos a vicious cycle ndash they lose skills, they become isolated, they dont make relationships.ldquoWe have clients who have been in these places for years, or people who may have been in one then moved to another and another, theres no support to get them into a flat.He explained: ldquoWhile the cost can be high, it is what we must pay to ensure people have somewhere to live when they are homeless.ldquoThese are the consequences of decades of underinvestment in social housing.Annie Wells, Scottish Conservative MSP for Glasgow said: ldquoThese revelations expose an extremely poor standard of living for those housed in these places. Itrsquos simply not good enough, either for the vulnerable people living there or the taxpayer.ldquoHow can we expect homeless people to get their lives back on track when theyrsquore being left in such unacceptable conditions Labour housing spokeswoman Pauline McNeill said: "This is simply scandalous but it wont be fixed until we end Scotlands housing crisis."The government need to be much better at preventative work and stopping people getting to this point in the first place."That means properly resourcing public services, looking at how we can make the private rented sector more affordable and preventing evictions, as well as building more homes for social rent."Current legislation on breaching suitable accommodation must be properly enforced and responded to ndash that simply is not happening now."Glasgow City Council said: ldquoThis is a national issue, and it should be noted that the charges for this type of accommodation go to support the whole homelessness system and the charges levied reflect the overall costs of the service."The charges are iniably met from Housing Benefit, which is paid for by the UK Government.ldquoWe are implementing the Housing First programme which will see people given permanent accommodation with appropriate support at the first time of asking.

title: david-pratt-in-the-eye-of-the-storm
story: It might as well have devastated the dark side of the moon for all the attention it has been given. But then itrsquos in Africa, isnrsquot it  These things happen there, have done before and doubtless will again, so whatrsquos new If I had the proverbial pound for every time such cynical responses have crossed my path after ing home from covering humanitarian crises across the African subcontinent and where these past decades, then the needy coffers of aid agencies would be better off right now.It was late on Thursday, March  when Cyclone Idai made landfall off the coast of Mozambique, before hurtling itrsquos gargantuan wrecking ball of mph winds, rain and floods into Zimbabwe and Malawi, causing devastation across swathes of all three countries.What Idai left in its wake has been described as perhaps the worst weather-related disaster ever to hit the southern hemisphere. Already the United Nations World Food Programmehas declared the flood crisis a level three emergency, putting it in the same bracket with Yemen, Syria and South Sudan.In terms of its impact for the estimated . million people caught up in this maelstrom, it meant storm surges of up to  feet deep, creating on the Mozambican coast what BBC reporter Fergal Keane flying over the area by helicopter called an ldquoinland sea.For tens of thousands it has meant being trapped by floods, landslides, flattened homes and flooded communities, with crops, roads and electricity supplies wiped away. More than , people needed emergency evacuation in the Mozambican port city of Beira alone where the cyclone made landfall. Some initial reports estimate that % of Beira, Mozambiquersquos fourth-largest city, with more than , residents, may be damaged or destroyed. Without electricity Beira has found itself in the dark and has become a ghost town at night.Many in Beira and where were stuck on rooftops or on tiny islands of land surrounded by water with no food, clean drinking water or shelter. There have been cases of women with babies trapped in trees and other lucky survivors pulled from neck-deep water.As ever in such situations, many of those worst affected were already the poorest of the poor, susceptible to hunger and disease even before Idai dealt them such another cruel blow.ldquoThis will have the worst impact on those most vulnerable, says Caroline Rose, Medecins Sans Frontieres head of mission in Mozambique.ldquoItrsquos those who have small, fragile houses that are worst impacted, as they are always the people without the means to build a new house. So itrsquos a vicious cycle.ldquoThose who have no means to rebuild will be left outside with no house, more at risk of disease and worse off.Aid organisations are of one voice in stressing that itrsquos now a race against the clock to prevent an even worse catastrophe emerging through the spread of disease.ldquoWe are running out of time, it is at a critical point here, warned the United Nations childrenrsquos agencychief Henrietta Fore on Friday.ldquoTherersquos stagnant water, itrsquos not draining, decomposing bodies, lack of good hygiene and sanitation, Fore said. ldquoWe are worried about cholera, about malaria, because of the stagnant water.As ever, humanitarians will have their work cut out harnessing the collective concern of a world that has so far been disproportionately low.As ever too, those cynics will chant their now familiar mantra about it being far away in Africa and how ldquocharity begins at home.To those among such people I would simply ask this. Imagine, just imagine, waking up tomorrow and the sense of desperation you would feel were your own children confronted with the same horrors so many in Mozambique, Zimbabwe and Malawi face right now How dferent the callous attitudes of such cynics might be were they, even momentarily, to eyewitness such suffering for themselves up close.The chaos, pain, helplessness, hunger and disease of such disasters are not an easy thing to confront face on and forget. The juxtaposition with the comparative safety and luxury so many of us take for granted here would also be a real shock to the sensibility of many.I well recall many years ago when the impact of climate change was dismissed more readily than it is now, ing from Ethiopia where millions were caught in the grip of drought and impending famine.It was just days before Christmas when I set foot back in Glasgow. The conspicuous consumption of that time of year stood in grotesque marked contrast to a village where I had been just a few days before, watching vultures circling above a community where people were already badly malnourished and some had died of hunger.ldquoWe call them the undertaker birds, one elderly local man told me, bringing home the terrible resignation so many people feel towards their fate when faced with such helplessness.Idairsquos angry arrival in Africa was yet another ominous sign for a continent already bearing the brunt of climate change. How tragically ironic it was that the cyclone made landfall on precisely the same day that the One Planet Summit, called by French president Emmanuel Macron, opened in the Kenyan capital Nairobi. In the same week too as Idai caused unimaginable levels of devastation, the Africa Climate Week conference got under way in Accra, Ghana.No doubt delegates at both conferences were again reminded that while Africa is responsible for only % of global greenhouse-gas emissions, climate change is considered to directly impact % of the African population.Those in any doubt that Africa is the continent that pays the highest price for this need only have tuned into breaking news reports of Idairsquos arrival to be reminded of what this means for millions of people.As environmental journalist Landry Ninteretse who leads the campaigning organisation Africa  has pointed out, for Africans ldquoclimate change is not a future risk, itrsquos already a reality evident in wrecked families, lands and livelihoods, and hopeless children and young people who have no choice but to seek a future by migrating.Perhaps those same cynics who complain about foreign aid and the ldquodeluge of migrants Europe faces should pause and consider this unrelenting impact of climate change. This, after all, is one of the prime reasons why so many of those plucked out of the seas or who drown trying to reach Europe are from the African subcontinent.Somewhere down the line you can be sure that Cyclone Idai and other disasters will send more on such perilous journeys.As Ninteretse says, Idai is just the latest reminder that everywhere on the African continent communities fear losing their land as each season hits one country after another with exceptional floods, unexpected storms and increasingly long droughts.It goes without saying thata tragedy of such gargantuan proportions as Idai occurred in the Western or ldquodeveloped world, then the response would be very dferent. Two vast cyclones named Trevor and Veronica are currently bearing down on the north coast of Australia and thousands have evacuated their homes in preparation for these two potentially devastating storms.Not for a moment to dismiss the suffering, destruction and potential loss of le these cyclones will bring to Australians, but itrsquos almost a certainty we will hear much more about their impact there than what has occurred in Africa this past week.Some will argue that it has always be thus, that there has been a huge disparity between how we handle humanitarian crises close to home or those that affect ldquorecognisable locations and how we process disasters that occur where.Butthere is one thing that the cycle of climate change and migration has shown us itrsquos that such humanitarian concerns are inextricably connected and transnational in nature affecting us all in one way or another wherever we might be.There are those who will argue that we cannot be sure that the likes of Idai was caused by climate change. But global experts agree that climate change certainly made it worse and point to three factors.First, warmer air temperatures mean more rain is held and then released. Idai produced nearly a yearrsquos worth of rain in just a few days, more than two feet in parts of the region.Second, the region has been suffering from sustained drought in recent years, itself a problem associated with climate change.As Unicef chief Henrietta Fore has pointed out, the water that has arrived has not drained.
