title: brexit only two weeks to avoid an accidental no deal paris gourtsoyannis
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...The UK#s Brexit fate is now in the hands of Remain-supporting Cabinet ministers and the other European Union member statesit is to avoid no deal, writes Paris Gourtsoyannis.You wouldnâ€™t normally base your political expectations on a chat in the pub. But when the guy propping up the bar is Theresa Mayâ€™s top Europe advisor, Olly Robbins â€“ the architect of her strategy in Brussels and the ERGâ€™s favourite hate figure â€“ you should safely be able to draw your Brexit roadmap from it.When ITV reported a second-hand overheard conversation in a Brussels bar where Robbins described how MPs would end up being presented with the option of Mayâ€™s Brexit deal or a long delay, it seemed to offer a key that would unlock the whole process of leaving the EU.After MPs voted against no-deal last week and for an extension to Article , events appeared to be following Robbinsâ€™ script perfectly. The Government had hoped to bring the deal back for a third vote this week, with the threat of Â­staying in the EU for anywhere between nine and  months looming over Brexiteers, forcing them to fall into line. Personally, I admit to breathing a sigh of relief at the end of last weekâ€™s chaos, thinking that a plan was coming together.But nothing has been more corrosive over the past three years than the illusion of government Â­control, and some forces are beyond even Robbinsâ€™ reckoning. The fact that his plan was so dramatically derailed this week means that a no-deal Brexit â€“ always the legal default â€“ could now happen by Â­accident, unless there is an even Â­bigger twist in the week ahead.Rather than taking back control, the events of the past week put Mayâ€™s fate in the hands of either the EU, or pro-EU Tories who could oust her to defeat her Brexit vision.: No-deal Brexit would place food banks in â€˜dangerous positionâ€™, warns Ian BlackfordNo one in Government predicted John Bercowâ€™s intervention Â­ruling out a third vote on the Brexit deal unless there was a signicant change in content or circumstances. That in itself is worrying â€“ the convention that motions canâ€™t be voted on twice in the parliamentary session isnâ€™t an obscure one. No one needs more evidence that Downing Street is floundering, but there it is.His critics say Bercowâ€™s intervention was an attempt to block Brexit and allow the second EU referendum he really wants, or at least rule out a no-deal scenario. By ruling out a vote before yesterdayâ€™s EU Council summit, the Â­Commons Speaker certainly denied the Â­Government its best chance of Â­getting the deal through.Bercowâ€™s statement forced the EU Commissionâ€™s chief Brexit Â­negotiator Michel Barnier to come out the following day and say a long extension needed a â€œclear purposeâ€. It also gave time for Â­Brexiteers in the Cabinet to ambush May and force her to take a request for a long extension off the table.The spectre aimed at scaring Brexiteers was vanquished, Â­leaving opposition MPs as the only pool of votes to pass the deal. Mayâ€™s extraordinary statement in Downing Street, shting the blame onto parliament, burnt that bridge, too.With ious extension plans being discussed during intense talks in Brussels last night, EU leaders appear to have come to the conclusion that May, and her deal, are finished.If she isnâ€™t in control, to avoid a no-deal Brexit the UK is now in the hands of two groups: Remainers in the Cabinet, and the  governments of the EU.A group of pro-EU Cabinet Â­ministers have insisted they would do whatever it takes to stop no-deal. They may now have the time to show they mean it.Both Barnier and French president Emmanuel Macron have said there is a way back,the UK is ready for â€œdeep political changeâ€.This could be a general election or a second EU referendum, but what the EU really wants to hear is that the red lines that have made a deal so dficultare going to be jettisoned, either by May, or her successor.The Remain group in Cabinet includes Scottish Secretary David Mundell, who joined Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke in breaking a three-line whip to abstain on a motion to extend Article  last week. With so little time left, resignation isnâ€™t enough. They would have to become the â€˜men and women in grey suitsâ€™, insisting the Prime Minister abandons her red lines, or ushering her out of Â­Downing Street.The likes of David Lidington would need to lead a government of national unity in all but name, getting a Brexit deal through with Labour and SNP votes that keeps the UK in the single market and customs union. It would likely mean the end of the Conservative Party as we know it at the very least, it would leave it to the next Tory leader to put its surviving pieces back together.: Jeremy Corbyn wonâ€™t rule out stopping Brexit as PM arrives in BrusselsEven in Brexit Britain, a week canâ€™t possibly hold that much drama, but a longer extension offers the opportunity.Still, EU leaders canâ€™t give the UK something it isnâ€™t prepared to ask for itself. Conservative MPs lost the chance to push May from office when they failed to do the job before Christmas. The UKâ€™s venerable Â­parliamentary democracy has shown itself not to be nimble enough for the last-minute pivot needed, and evenit could, its leaders command too little confidence to bring the public along with them.In EU capitals, an election or a new EU referendum looks like a leap into more uncertainty, which the Â­continent scarcely needs. Leaders and officials gathered in Brussels spoke openly about the â€œcrisisâ€ in the UK, and donâ€™t want their fragile politics infected by the febrile mood around Westminster.A no deal Brexit could still happen by accident. The only thing thatâ€™s certain is that Bercow and the EU have called time on Robbinsâ€™ pub blueprint.Â©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: euan mccolm history unmasks brexit fellow traveller corbyn
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Supporters of Jeremy Corbyn are hugely fond of making the claim that the Labour leader has always been on the right side of history.Whether defending him against troubling questions about his associations with representatives of sundry terrorist organisations or explaining why he could so often be found voting against past Labour governments, Corbynistas frequently rely on the line that their man has always had right on his side.This revisionist takemight baffle non-believers, but for those who have emotionally invested themselves in the Leader of the Opposition, itâ€™s more than enough to allow them to maintain the fantasy that he is a paragon of moral purity.I wonder how many of those supporters will â€“ after yesterdayâ€™s extraordinary march in London in support of a second EU referendum â€“ have the decency to, at least, die a little inside the next time they parrot this claptrap about the man who would be prime minister.Corbynâ€™s boycott of yesterdayâ€™s protest is nothing less than a betrayal of the very people â€“ the vulnerable, the poorly paid, the powerless â€“ who will be hit hardest by the United Kingdomâ€™s departure from the European Union. Whatâ€™s more, itâ€™s a betrayal of his own party which â€“ in theory, at least â€“ is in favour of another referendum on EU membership as a way of breaking the deadlock on the question.Corbynâ€™s closest political ally, shadow chancellor John McDonnell, explained that the reason he could not bring himself to attend yesterdayâ€™s event was that by doing so he might â€œalienateâ€ some of the people he wanted to â€œbring on boardâ€. Maybe this was good enough for the faithful, but it really shouldnâ€™t have been.On every political issue, there will always be those who take opposing views. If we apply McDonnell logic, those with whom a politician disagrees should never be challenged. Can you imagine a Corbynista arguing against protesting against, letâ€™s say, restrictions on trade union rights on the grounds that to do so might alienate those who are in favour  No, of course you canâ€™t.Across the broader left, arguments against participation in yesterdayâ€™s march were no less infantile.On Friday, Jonathon Shafi, co-counder of the Radical Independence Campaign, tweeted a list of participants in the march. These included Tories such as Michael Heseltine, Justine Greening and Dominic Grieve and Liberal Democrats Vince Cable and Jo Swinson. â€œHow anyone on the left can countenance supporting this,â€ he wrote, â€œI have no idea.â€One could easily draw up a list of those opposed to the objective of yesterdayâ€™s protest â€“ Prime Minister Theresa May, for example, and former Ukip leader Nigel Farage â€“ and ask how anyone on the left could countenance not participating in the march.The hard left â€“ the Jeremy Corbyn left â€“ has long been every bit as Eurosceptic  as the right. Theyâ€™re just less honest about it.Corbynâ€™s pitully weak role in the Remain campaign in  confirmed what anyone who had paid the slightest attention to his career already knew. He believed the EU was a malign force. Corbynâ€™s absence from yesterdayâ€™s march was not because there were Tories there and nor because he feared alienating Leavers, he was not there because he is the left cheek of the anti-EU arse. It is as simple as that.And so, as has become a modern tradition, it fell to Corbynâ€™s deputy â€“ Tom Watson â€“ to stand up for the values the Labour Party is supposed to hold dear.Treating his leader with the contempt he deserves, Watson said he was backing a second referendum as the only way to solve the Brexit crisis.He would be participating in â€“ and speaking at â€“ the Put It To The People march because the current parliamentary impasse was not working for either Leavers or Remainers.â€œIâ€™ve come to the reluctant view that the only way to resolve this, and have legitimacy in the eyes of the public, is for the people themselves to sign it off,â€ said Watson. The only chance of bringing the country back together was, he added, to give everyone a â€œfinal sayâ€ and then live with the result.To the screeching fury chimps who pollute the internet with abuse of anyone who dares criticise Corbyn, this will have been further confirmation that Watson is impure. I mean, he went on a march with Heseltine â€“ he must be a wrong â€™un, mustnâ€™t he The SNP has often deployed the â€œstanding with Toriesâ€ missile to attack Labour politicians who oppose Scottish independence but, yesterday, senior nationalists â€“ including party leader Nicola Sturgeon â€“ were happy to do precisely that.Sturgeon and her colleagues could find it within themselves to unite with political opponents in pursuit of a common goal, but for adherents of the Church of Corbyn such pragmatism is heresy.MPs may have voted to reject a No Deal Brexit â€“ and even Corbyn says such a scenario would be a mistake â€“ but unless they can agree an alternative thatâ€™s acceptable to the EU, it remains a distinct possibility.Corbyn supporters might indulge the fantasy he can win an election that hasnâ€™t actually been called and then strike a deal which works for the UK, but the reality is that they are fellow travellersâ€“ whether they like it or not â€“ of such Tory Brexiteers as Jacob Rees-Mogg and Dominic Raab. They are standing by, doing nothing, while Brexit looms, threatening jobs and diminishing the UK in the eyes of the rest of the world. Thatâ€™s not a display of moral courage but of craven capitulation.Corbynâ€™s leadership â€“one can characterise it as such â€“ of the Labour Party has been quite the rollercoaster ride. Elected as the champion of a new, gentler, kinder, more compassionate politics, he was long ago exposed as a drab, unpleasant little man whose ideas were forged â€“ and remain â€“ in the foreign country of the past. Supporters may tell themselves his boycott of yesterdayâ€™s march was a display of integrity but, in fact, it was just the latest in a long line of moments when Jeremy Corbyn was on the wrong side of history.Â©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: why scotland s roads aren t ready for electric scooters alastair dalton
story: Electric scooters are common in parts of Europe and the US and the UK Government is considering whether to allow them on British roads. Alastair Dalton explains why that would be a mistake.They offer a potentially attractive new way of getting about â€“ but also threaten chaos on Scotlandâ€™s car-centric road networks.Electric scooters are commonplace in some European countries and US states, and the UK Government is now considering whether to allow them here too.Ministers announced this week they will â€œconsider options for appropriate testing regimes to ensure any such vehicles on the road are safe and fit for purposeâ€, which could be followed by localised trials.On the face of it, being able to hop on and effortlessly zip about our towns and cities has obvious appeal â€“ especially to non-cyclists.It is hardly â€œactive travelâ€, like walking and cycling, but could encourage some to switch from cars or taxis on short journeys.Anything electrically powered, which has no emissions on the street, also has to be a positive as part of efforts to cut urban air pollution.However, letting loose a new form of transport on roads still woefully unsuited for cycles could just make things worse for everyone.Thatâ€™s not to say thereâ€™s not a case for them â€“ but the radical redrawing of road space away from the car should be accelerated first.The brave would take their chances scooting among other traffic, though many are likely to be deterred from sharing roads with lorries, buses and taxis, let alone the cars who already pass cyclists intimidatingly close.: Electric scooters on British roads would create â€˜dangerous cocktailâ€™Thereâ€™s also the small matter of scootersâ€™ in wheels not being pothole friendly, causing discomfortnot danger, as shared transport group Comouk has highlighted.Most who scoot are likely to want to stick to the relative safety of pavements and cycle lanes â€“that is permitted. But here, a dferent risk is created, of scooters colliding with pedestrians.There are far too few cycle lanes they could use, on roads or pavements, and even fewer segregated lanes, albeit cities like Glasgow are adding more.In addition, there is already potential conflict between walkers and cyclists on shared paths, some of which would struggle to cope with more riders, let alone scooters too.Another concern is street clutter. Recent visitors to Berlin and Brussels tell me of large numbers of scooters strewn across pavements.Technology may now enable scooters to be left â€œdocklessâ€, but this has caused a big problem in places like San Diego.Itâ€™s bad enough trying to negotiate pavements already littered with advertising A-boards, so this could cause another hazard.Karen Millhouse, a resident of the Calornian city, emailed me this week: â€œI think we have more than , dockless scooters in our fair city, and they just keep coming. It is a nightmare, especially for pedestrians and the disabled.â€She said Disability Rights Calornia had even filed a class action against scooters blocking pavements.: Alastair Dalton: The â€˜electric-bike smileâ€™ is now officialA better plan for Scotland â€“ and the UK â€“ would be to focus on electric bikes first. The main rental schemes in Edinburgh and Glasgow are due to add them later this year, along with other parts of Scotland such as Stirling.Electric bikes are equally effortless to ride, but unlike scooters provide nearly as much exercise as traditional cycling, so have much more to commend them.They also encourage people to cycle further, and have a similar topspeed â€“ mph â€“ as has been proposed for scooters.Â©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...A treasure trove of documents signed by Mary Queen of Scots and revealing the #everyday reality of ruling the country# in the th century has been unearthed in a council storage facility on the Royal Mile.A haul of handwritten papers is said to show the doomed monarch â€œcarefully managing the busy commercial le of Edinburghâ€, as well as authorising the building of new defences for the city in Leith.The documents, which are set to be the centrepiece of a new exhibition in Edinburgh on Maryâ€™s short-lived rule, have already been conserved and digitised to allow them to be viewed publicly on the councilâ€™s online archive. The  documents, which are inidually dated, numbered and signed, relate to the rights of deacons and tradesmen in the city, the selling of meat at the Tolbooth and the making of salt in Newhaven.Early conservation work on the documents, which were recently discovered in the Museum of Edinburghâ€™s own storage facility off the Canongate, has revealed watermarks â€“ one of a goat and another of a flower â€“ which can only been seen when held up to light.It is thought the papers entered the archives of the local authority in the s, but were then â€œlostâ€ before being rediscovered nearly a century later during conservation work. Intriguingly, some of the documents signed by Mary date from when she was still in France.Experts in the councilâ€™s museums and galleries service, which is responsible for the official archives of the city, said the recently unearthed documents revealed an â€œoften overlooked â€œ aspect of her le.History curator Vicky Garrington said: â€œTogether, the documents shed light on a key part of Scotlandâ€™s past. We all know the tragic story of Mary Queen of Scots, her eventful le and eventual execution in , but in these documents we see a dferent side to Mary.â€œHere, she can be seen carefully managing the everyday affairs of Edinburgh, both from France and Scotland. Itâ€™s fascinating to think of her reading through these official papers before carefully applying her signature.â€œThey are staying in storage at the museum for now. But we hope to have them assessed by a conservator and for further research to be done on them by experts on Mary, after which we hope to exhibit them, which will be hugely exciting.â€Museums and galleries manager Frank Little said: â€œWeâ€™re constantly reviewing, caring for and researching our collections, and look forward to sharing more of the cityâ€™s rich heritage with residents and visitors through our programme of exhibitions and online activities.â€ Council culture convener Donald Wilson said: â€œOur museums and galleries hold thousands of historic treasures, many of which are on display in our venues. He is an Osiwa Poetry Residency Fellow,  Moniack Mhor Poet in Residence, and his second poetry collection â€˜The Tragedy of Falling with Laughter Stuck in Your Throatâ€™, is due out this year.Tickets are available from seall.

title: portree pupils tackle brexit in school
story: An TÃ¬r, An CÃ nan, â€˜S na DaoineFor perhaps the first time since the then Prime Minister David Cameron announced the European referendum back in February , the cases for and against Brexit were made in a respectful, well-argued and comprehensively-researched manner during a lively debate.However, rather than taking place in the House of Commons, the arguments were heard in Skye as Portree High School pupils deliberated over the merits of the constitutional quandary during a debate held on Friday th March.Two teams comprising four pupils apiece from S to S argued for and against the motion stating that #This house believes that leaving the EU will be the best thing that#s ever happened to Britain#.The debate was chaired by the former head of programme for BBC Scotland, Maggie Cunningham, and judged by a  made up of Charlie BaptieAlasdair Rossand Carole Inglis .The teams were asked to deliver an opening address to provide an outline of the points they would be arguing. They then went on to highlight some of the key tenets underpinning the debate such as trade agreements, law and immigration, before making their concluding statements.In the opening gambit for the pro-Brexit team, S pupil Abbi Morgan argued that leaving the EU #would be a hugely positive thing for the UK# and would allow the country to #take control of borders and create worldwide trade agreements#.She went on to add that it would put the UK in a position to #take back its sovereignty# and make its own decisions on important matters. She stated that as a net contributor to the EU, the UK would be better off by Â£. billion.In the opening address for the pro-EU team, Lois Langlandssaid that #history and past experience as a member of the EU# gave the UK a more secure position for the future and that, in leaving the European Union, the UK would #enter the unknown# and #walk into the future blindfolded#.She said that outside the EU the UK was a #small fish in a big pond# and asked why any country would be interested in providing a free trade agreement with the UK.#The EU as an organisation is extremely wasteful#, he said. #Every  days the European Parliament moves from Brussels to Strasbourg, where it sits for four days # this is estimated to cost nearly Â£ million a year.#Touching on the issues of freedom of movement as part of the remain team, Chiara MacLeansaid: #Once the UK leaves the EU, British citizens will become third-party nationals, with no automatic right of admission.# She added that, through the new European travel information and authorisation system, all UK nationals over  years of age #would have to pay money to go somewhere they had a free right to go now#.Seth Bennettook up the reins for the pro-Brexit side, arguing that in terms of laws and immigration the EU could pass any laws they wanted and in by doing so #strip Britain of its sovereignty# # which he described as #one of its driving forces#.He believed that Brexit would offer the UK the chance to #increase its spending in education and housing# which could perhaps lead to a #revival of the nation#s once-thriving industries#.Speaking for the pro-EU team, Gracie Buchan said that leaving the European Union would lead to a trade deficit and result in a shortage of daily supplies such as fruit and vegetables.#Keeping food shop shelves full and prices down will be one of the biggest challenges when Brexit comes around,# she said. #Failure to reach some sort of an agreement could see retailers face an average increase of  per cent, particularly in dairy, meat, veg, and fruit.#Closing for the Brexit side, S pupil Joseph Moller said the EU favoured its own agenda and that in terms of per head of population Maltese citizens had  times more representation than UK nationals.He added that, rather than the , jobs that were cited as potentially being lost due to Brexit, the level of employment had in fact risen by one per cent since the referendum and unemployment was at its lowest level since the s.Summing up for remain, S pupil Innes MacNeil said: #Latest reports suggest that deals have been struck with just seven out of  countries, we have gained a lot more than we have spent on the EU, and multinational companies are threatening to relocate overseas, affecting jobs and investments.#Exiting in less than  days# time without any sound withdrawal agreement and just a few trade relationships will result in uncertainty and chaos.#The judges said they were impressed by how confident and informed the pupils were. They also felt the pupils were cohesive as a team and said that they saw some future MSPs and MPs.In the end, the judges awarded the team speaking against Brexit  points while the side advocating Brexit received  to claim victory.Skye, Lochaber, and Badenoch MSP Kate Forbes and Highland and Islands MSP Edward Mountain both fielded questions on Brexit after the debate and were quick to praise the pupils for their efforts.Ms Forbes said: #I certainly think they could have resolved Brexit faster than some of the politicians today # an absolutely fantastic debate based on fact, evidence, respect for each other, lots of confidence. I think I have left with a few top tips for my next debate in parliament!#Mr Mountain added: #I thought it was quite excellent # there#s obviously a lot of research gone into it. I thought they were extremely confident # I would have been much more nervous than that speaking at their age. As I said to Kate Forbes today, she should be worried because there are a few challenges for her position.#

title: lewis and harris womens football team kick off new league in
story: An TÃ¬r, An CÃ nan, â€˜S na Daoine with a barnstorming - away win over Nairn Ladies FC.The long trip to Nairn for their league opener on Saturday proved to be one to remember for the islanders as they enjoyed a resounding victory to get their league campaign up and running in emphatic fashion.Played in freezing conditions on Nairn showfield, the Lewis and Harris club fielded a young side made up largely of - and -year-olds # with just three non-pupil players included in the squad.After missing a penalty, Ann-Mairi Macleod made history by becoming the scorer of the first goal in the newly-formed Highlands and Islands league.Macleod#s goal opened the floodgates as the visitors went on to score five more in the first period # thanks to a goal apiece from Jessica Macleod and Hollie Martin, and a hat-trick from Mary Macleod.Lewis and Harris were in dreamland in the second half as they proceeded to score a further  goals. title: psni hosts christian groups
story: A gathering of Christian outreach groups was hosted by the Mid and East Antrim police at Ballymenaâ€™s PSNI station on Tuesday, March  to discuss the possibilities for improved collaboration and communication, and to launch a new signposting initiative.Around  iniduals representing  dferent outreach ministries in Ballymena met with the local Neighbourhood policing team.Groups attending included foodbanks, debt-advice, anti-trafficking, sports coaching for youth, senior citizens support, mother and toddler, and English Language classes, amongst others.The event focused on the possibilities for greater collaboration between the churches, ministries, and the PSNI to improve cohesion, communication, and to explore ways in which we can work together to bring help and support of ious kinds to those needing it in our community.The event was facilitated by Without Walls in conjunction with Chief Inspector Stephen Humphrieswho hosted the event. There was input from Chief Inspector Humphries on burning issues facing the Mid  East Antrim policing district.Assistant Chief Constable Mark Hamilton attended the evening and spoke in support of the Signposting project and to encourage churches and outreach groups to partner more with the police to help make communities safer places. Recently retired Chief Superintendent Stephen Cargin also commended this initiative and gave several examples of where such collaboration is working successfully. Jonathan Leakey and Philip McCartney of the Without Walls team introduced the new signposting booklet and web resource that a number of organisations including agencies, charities and church ministries have contributed to, aimed at helping people in whatever kind of need to access the help and support from agencies and ministries in the town.

title: slate records that henry kerr was here way back in 1835
story: GRACEHILL Old School Trustmade a wonderful discovery when they commenced the restoration of the Old Village Shop in the village recently.Perched high on the roof and undisturbed for many years was a slate neatly inscribed â€œHenry Kerr reslated this house in the year â€The Trust purchased the historic old village shop and former post office in  with the help of the then Ballymena Borough Council and the Environment Agency. Since then emergency repairs have been undertaken as the building had been unoccupied for a number of years following the deaths of Jim and Sally Gillen, Gracehillâ€™s last postmasters. Happily, a full scheme of restoration is now underway. The first phase will see the building of new chimneys, the replacement of the roof and rainwater goods and repairs to the windows. The building is historically very signicant as it was a purpose built shop constructed for the Settlement in . It is two storey with attics and basement and the layout is much as it was when originally constructed. The central shop area still contains many original features including shelving built into the walls, counters and a large wooden winch wheel for drawing stores up to the attic. Speaking about the restoration David Johnston, chairman of the Trust said: The aim is to restore this unique building so visitors can once again experience what le might have been like in the nineteenth century. â€œHoliday accommodation with a period theme will also be provided and a tea room will complete the scheme to ensure the future of this wonderful and historic building and hopefully the roof will be good for another  years!

title: midtown makers celebrate international women s day
story: International Womens Daywas celebrated in many countries around the world on March .The aim of the day is to recognize women for their achievements without regard to isions, whether national, ethnic, linguistic, cultural, economic or political. International Womens Day first emerged from the activities of labour movements at the turn of the twentieth century in North America and across Europe.Each year International Womens Day has a dferent theme and this yearâ€™s theme was #BalanceforBetter.Midtown Makers decided to celebrate the success of all women within the local community including Midtown Makers and Ballymena Business Centre. The Ballymena celebration took place in Midtown Makers Studio and Shop on Friday March , where over  women attended from business, community and the creative sector.Sponsored by Ballymena Business Centre exhibitions included Womenâ€™s Rights as promoted by the Suffragettes Lace maker, Sarah McMullan Vis art, by women for women and finally, Ceris Art, Laughing Therapy. The event also hosted several inspirational speakers including, Cllr Audrey Wales MBE, Director Ballymena Business Centre Lucy Craig, Netty Hill BID Manger, Motivational Speaker Kathleen McBride Cllr Lindsay Millar, Mayor of Mid and East Antrim Borough Council and Mary Hamilton, Director Ballymena Business Centre.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim Cllr Lindsay Millar said: â€œI am very proud to be here today to celebrate successful women.â€œTo hear their inspiring stories is humbling and also empowering as we face many challenges in le, so what better way to encourage each other than by sharing what weâ€™ve learnt.â€œAs Mayor I wanted to open the role and the office to more women, young and old. Events like this are an amazing way to remind ourselves as women that we can and are achieving great things.â€Many of the local retailers also helped celebrate International Womenâ€™s Day by donating gts that were used in a raffle. A fantastic amount of pound was raised and all the money is being donated to Crafty Wellness, a charity started by Midtown Crafters to help women who are in need of support. title: new motorway was the talk of the town
story: March and April  were quiet in Ballymena regarding the outbreaking â€˜Troublesâ€™ taking place in other parts of Northern Ireland - however plenty of local news was making the headlines.March  saw Councillors in the spotlight once more as members of the Ulster Protestant Volunteersheld a picket protest outside the Town Hall before a Council meeting.The protest came after a rally where Rev Ian Paisley had addressed the crowd.The UPV were annoyed that Council had refused them permission to use the Town Hall for a Protestant rally in February, and so they were showing their views via the protest.Some of their placards read: Welcome to Ballymena, the graveyard of democracy while others read: Democracys Executioners.Although the protest was silent, their presence was well felt.Mobile BankingMeanwhile, there was good news for the area as the countrys first mobile bank was rolled out in Ballymena and district.The Bank of Ireland set up Banking on the Doorstep to bring the bank to people in rural areas who found it dficult to travel into town.This brought signicant credit to the local area as it was the first place such a service was introduced. The then mayor of Ballymena took great pleasure in launching the service at Leighinmohr House Hotel.Such a service does not exist today, however many would argue there is no need for it as most people have access to a car or indeed online banking, a feat not yet possible in !Oâ€™Neill faces protestorsThe then Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, Terence ONeill faced protesters at Randalstown Orange Hall while he was addressing Bannside constituents.He faced calls inside the meeting, with people shouting: â€œONeill wont go!â€Â to which Randalstown Unionist Dr. Bolton Minford responded: â€œONeill is here, ONeill isnt going and he wont go!â€ Meanwhile, a group of â€˜extreme Protestantsâ€™ in the audience of nearly  people gave the Prime Minister a noisy reception as he spoke to Bannside constituents. About  followers of Rev Ian Paisley heckled and shouted Capt. ONeill down and a tomato was thrown at the , however it struck a Ballymena reporter!Eggs were then thrown at the Prime Minister as he left the hall. Entrance to the meeting was by ticket only, however it was announced that some forged tickets were going around so people had to identy themselves before gaining entry in.AprilFlooding was a concern in April .There were talks about total immunity from flooding from the Rivers Maine and Braid however this would have led to great expense and would have involved a major programme of bridge reconstruction and widespread interference with domestic and industrial property.Vandals were a source of annoyance as they caused damage to the pound, sports pavilion at the John Simpson Memorial Playing Fields off the Wakehurst Road.In Sport in April , Ballymena Academy had reached the semi-finals of the Rugby Schools Cup. However, sadly for the local boys, they lost for the second year in a row with a score of  points to  to Campbell.Ballymenaâ€™s MThe main news of the month was the opening of the new M Bypass road, which world provide a motorway alternative to the main town centre.This poundmillion piece of road was officially opened by Mr Nat Minford who was Secretary of State at the Ministry of Development at the time.It was hoped this new road would solve much of the towns congestion problems as much of the traffic would now use the new five and a half mile stretch of motorway.There were concerns that the by-pass would steal trade away from the town centre, however as the opening day drew near, town centre traders were starting to conform to the opinion that reduced congestion in the centre would actually attract people to the shops.A specially equipped Jaguar police car was deployed to carry out a highway patrol.Carrying a highly experienced team of police officers, the car was able to be in constant radio contact with traffic control in Ballymena.The car was a white . litre illuminated police car that was crammed full with ious emergency items.The back seats were even removed to stow flashing red lamps and large signs to warn of accidents.The two officers who had the pleasure of driving the specially designed car were Constables John McConnell and Wesley Russell, who both had special training for the motorway patrol.Specic advice was given to motorists on how to use the road, as this was the first motorway in the mid-Antrim area.Users were warned to drive within their own capabilities and those of their vehicle and they were reminded that right turns are not permitted!Do you remember the opening of the M bypass If so, wed love to hear from you on your memories of when you first got to drive on Ballymenas motorway!

title: stephens catering staff abseil europa
story: AN adventurous group of employees from Stephens Catering Equipment reached great heights last month as they abseiled their way to an amazing pound, for Northern Ireland Chest, Heart and Stroke charity.The  strong team took part in the charity abseil at the Europa Hotel on Sunday, February , and what made this even more of a challenge for the team is that most of them are afraid of heights!Just before the event, Claire Adair explained: â€œThis is the first abseil for most of us and a real challenge.â€œI wanted to arrange a charity event that will really make us face our fears.â€œMost of us taking part have a fear of heights so it will be a huge challenge. Personally, I am petried!â€œWe are all from Ballymena or surrounding areas.â€œStephens Catering Equipment is based in Broughshane with offices in Dublin, Donegal and Belfastâ€œMy family and friends must think I have gone mad knowing my fear of heights.â€œI wanted to arrange a challenge to really make people fight their fears.â€œI know when we have completed the abseil we will have a huge sense of achievement.â€And the team really did rise to the challenge, scaling down the tall hotel building and helping to raise thousands for this importanat charity.Claire added: â€œMy place of work, Stephens Catering Equipment, worked closely with NICHS last year in increasing employeesâ€™ health and well-being and many changes have been made in our workplace and our home lives.â€œMany of us have family or friends that have been affected with illnesses relating to Chest Heart or Stroke and by raising funds for the charity they can continue their amazing work in Northern Ireland.â€œPersonally, my parents both passed away in  with chest related issues so I know the importance of the charities work. We have also recently ran a raffle in aid of NICHS raising pound, with fabulous prizes donated from local businesses.â€œStephens Catering Equipment are also in the process of getting a Defibrillator which will be located in our building and available for use within the community during office hours.

title: leighinmohr house gets planning permission to add 12 more bedrooms
story: PLANNING permission has been granted to Leighinmohr House Hotel for an extension their premises.The established hotel on Leighinmohr Avenue applied for permission to extend the hotel in order to create  new bedrooms over two floors and additional kitchen facilities to the rear of the hotel. Mid  East Antrim Councilâ€™s Planning Committee heard there were  objections from local residents naming issues surrounding sound, the scale of the project, odour, surface water flooding, ground contamination, light spill and increased traffic.However planner Kyle Patterson told the meeting that there had been no objections from Transport NI, NI Water, The Rivers Agency and Mid and East Antrim Council, subject to conditions. Mr Patterson also confirmed that this planning application had made signicant changes to that of an initial submission last year. The modications include the extension being reduced to two stories, as opposed to the original . stories.Councillors were also told that the proposed extensions would respect the established character and appearance of the main building as well as that of the surrounding area.Full planning permission was recommended to be approved by the planning officers.Addressing Councillors, the owner of the hotel, Adrian Fullan said: â€œAlong with my business partner we purchased the hotel five years ago. We now have  full time staff and  part time employees. We provide poundm in wages to the local borough.â€Mr Fullan also said that the wedding business of the hotel had grown and they now need more space as their business was increasing.DUP Councillor Beth Adger propsed that permission would be granted, which was seconded by fellow DUP Councillor Audrey Wales, who said: â€œThis is really in line with our tourism objectives, and it will be good to offer  more bedrooms to tourists to the area.â€ Permission was unanimously agreed.

title: ni climbing frames is tops
story: A cutting-edge business programme designed to support and grow local micro and small sized enterprises has engaged with over  local companies during the last four years and successfully helped create over  jobs across the Borough.The innovative Business Engagement Programme , managed by Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council, provides tailored mentoring to businesses â€“ with NI Climbing Frames being one such company to avail of this assistance.Based in Banbridge, NI Climbing Frames design, manufacture and install climbing frames for both the private and commercial market. They made contact with the BEP because they wanted expert help on how they could grow their business by developing the market in the Republic of Ireland.The company received  hours of one-to-one mentoring aimed at helping to create a marketing strategy, specically targeting sales growth in RoI. The mentor spent several months working closely with the business to produce this specic plan â€“ and the outcome has been hugely successful.As a direct result of the programme support, NI Climbing Frames has seen sales increase in RoI by a massive  per cent! On top of this, thanks to additional support through the programme, a new business development position was created and is part funded by the InterTradeIreland Acumen programme.The mentor also advised the company to pro-actively seek out Research and Development tax claim relief, which has helped the business to invest further and contribute to this growth.â€œIt is fantastic to see the direct impact that the Business Engagement Programme has had on so many of our local businesses, to ensure that they can continue to grow and thrive in what can often be a dficult economic climate,â€ commented Councillor Paul Greenfield, Chair of Economic Development and Regeneration Committee.â€œCouncil is committed to supporting our local businesses and this ground breaking programme ensures practical support where it is most needed. I was delighted to meet with Ricardo at NI Climbing Frames and to see first-hand how this programme has benefited the growth of his business and opened up a whole new range of opportunities for the future.â€Ricardo Manso, Managing Director of NI Climbing Frames said, â€œThe Business Engagement Programme was brilliant as it allowed us to get expert advice on issues relevant to NI Climbing Frames. Time was set aside to look at a iety of matters including things that were working well for us and things that could be improved. Then, with the help of the programme, we were given some brilliant advice and goals to work towards. We have now increased our production, sales and hired more staff and much of this is due to the programme.â€The Business Engagement Programme is part funded by Invest NI and the European Regional Development Fund under the Investment for Growth and Jobs Northern IrelandProgramme.To be eligible for assistance from this programme, your business must be located in the Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council area, employ less than  people, be actively trading and not currently receiving similar support from where.For more information, please contact Noelle Garvey on    or email noelle.garvey@armaghbanbridgecraigavon.gov.ukABC Council issues telephone numbers to support local teens caught up in Cookstown tragedyPolice appeal for safe St Patrickâ€™s Day Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BANB | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BANB | Article Teaser"

title: a taste of italy right on your doorstep
story: IF you have ever been to Italy before, you will know just how good the local food can be. From pizza to pasta, Italian food is right up there with so many peopleâ€™s tastebuds.As a lover of all things Italian, I was hugely excited when the Balmoral Hotel recently started their â€˜Italian Nightâ€™, available every Tuesday night from -pm. I am no stranger to the thriving Blackâ€™s Road establishment and given the quality of food available in the Lady Anne Bistro and the conjoining Stix # Stones, the special-themed night attracted me to pay a visit once again to the Balmoral last Tuesday night.As ever, we were greeted by a polite and accommodating member of staff on arrival and shown to our table. I was immediately drawn by the dÃ©cor â€“ a number of Italian flags scattered around the restaurant and a huge blazing fire which was the perfect welcoming as Storm Gareth continued to rage outside.The themed-menu consists of a range of dishes sought to bring out the authentic taste of Italy and I couldnâ€™t wait to peruse my choices. From pizzas to lasagne and pasta, there looked to be something for everyone, with gluten-free options also available.Before we had made our choice, we were presented with a large plate of Italian antipasti â€“ basically a mixture of famous Italian nibbles. Much to my surprise, this is a complimentary touch from the Balmoral on the Italian night, designed to delve you into the full authentic Italian experience straight away.I gazed excitedly at my partner across the table. Where would we start  There were sticks of garlic bread, doughballs, pepperoni, olives and a pasta salad. Add in some jalapenos, peppers with a mouth-watering vinaigrette and mozzarella, it was a sublime clash of flavours which made me feel right inâ€¦ well Italy! It reminded me much like a version of Spanish Tapas or Chinese Dim Sum which allows for iety and quantity of dferent options. With quality too, the night was off to a flyer with this beautul antipasti starter.On to the main course and after the wonderful starter, me and my partner could not wait for it to arrive. We both went for pizza, and to be honest it would be hard not to given the mouth-watering choices on the menu. A superb handcrafted gourmet pizza range, inidually designed with the finest ingredients for your own authentic taste of Italy â€“ it was simply a no-brainer.After much deliberation, I opted for the BBQ Pizza, which consisted of a BBQ sauce base, mozzarella, chorizo, peri-peri chicken, jalapenos, onions and sweetcorn. Drizzled with just amount the peri-peri sauce, it was a concoction of flavours. A thin-base is always a must for me in order to properly enjoy what is actually on the pizza, instead of having to chew excessive amounts of pizza dough and again this pizza ticked all the right boxes. A BBQ-base and chicken on a pizza is nothing out of the ordinary on a pizza menu but this one was unique, given the intense flavour from the peri-peri sauce. This pizza would put some â€œItalianâ€ pizza takeaways to shame, quite frankly. It was that good.Across the table, my partner, who is a vegetarian is no stranger to a good old pizza, after all it is entirely possible to enjoy the classic Italian dish without any meat at all. The menu includes a fantastic make-your-own option from an ingredient list with everything you can think of on it, allowing you to be as adventurous as you like. She went for a classic tomato base complete with mozzarella and a generous helping of sweetcorn, peppers and jalapenos. The pizza looked like a veggieâ€™s delight and again it could not be faulted. Not too heavy on the stomach and full of flavour, it was little surprise she deliberately wanted to keep a few slices to take home.The pizzas also allow for additional sides, and it wouldnâ€™t be an Italian night without some Garlic Bread. I simply adore anything garlic and this was what garlic bread should be like â€“ oozing with garlic butter as it was torn apart, you could tell it was handcrafted and homemade to perfection. Our additional side of garlic potatoes also trumped the other side options of skinny fries or a tossed salad. It was a carbs heaven evening overall but worth it for the quality and taste of the food we enjoyed.A packed Tuesday night in the Lady Anne Bistro could only mean other diners, like ourselves, were enjoying the authentic Italian-themed menu on offer. It was something very unique and to their credit, the wonderful team of chefs and staff at the Balmoral are pulling it off to perfection. Most of the pizzas are priced around the Â£ mark which is more than worth it, just think how expensive it can be to order a takeaway from some well-known establishments. The Balmoral Hotel is excelling and the Italian-themed night is just the latest incentive to what is a fantastic establishment. Warm and friendly staff, quality food and best of all, itâ€™s right on your doorstep. I could not recommend the Italian night anymore. Go and check it out for yourself and tell me you donâ€™t feel like you have been to Italy for the night. I cannot wait to plan my next Tuesday nightvisit.Balmoral Hotel,Blacks Road, Dunmurry, Belfast BT NFTel:    balmoralhotelbelfast.co.u

title: butsy was larger than life and loved by many
story: BORN on September   the late Pat â€˜Butsyâ€™ Butler has been described as a â€œlarger than le figureâ€ andâ€œsomeone who was known and loved by manyâ€.Pat, who passed away on December  , was educated at St Teresaâ€™s Primary School on the Glen Road, before moving to St Malachyâ€™s College where he completed his secondary education. The Glen Road manâ€™s first job was as a compositor printer with Pitmanâ€™s University Press. However, during these early working days, he undertook voluntary youth work within the greater West Belfast area and soon realised that this was where his future lay. Eventually Pat left Belfast for Leicester University where he achieved his degree in youth and social care, following this up with a Masterâ€™s degree from the Ulster University. Pat eventually became a youth worker in charge at St Michaelâ€™s Youth Club, Finaghy Road North, where he spent many happy years. During this time, Pat managed a number of the youth football teams, with home games being played at Woodlands playing fields. Patâ€™s brothers commented that to say he was â€œvocerousâ€ in his coaching would be an â€œunderstatementâ€. â€œIn fact the story goes that at this time, house prices in Orchardville depreciated by  per cent!â€At a time when West Belfast was often in turmoil, the youth club was a haven for young people a place where parents knew their children would be safe. Pat took this onboard and enabled the young people in his care to reach their full potential. Pat developed an insatiable love for sport from a very early age. He joined Davittâ€™s GAC for a short time before transferring to St Agnesâ€™ where he spent many happy years as both a player and manager. In the course of his time with the â€˜Aggiesâ€™ Pat, along with many of the players, made those never to be forgotten trips to the continent and of course Shannon events that proved to be hugely enjoyable and deeply spitural ventures. A serious arm break when he was  curtailed Patâ€™s playing career but he had much success in his managerial roles. Pat, affectionately known as Butsy, also loved soccer and had a long and enjoyable time playing for and supporting Dominic Savio. During the â€™s, Pat embraced the basketball scene and in particular St Gallâ€™s basketball club. Pat was committed totally to this new undertaking. In fact, his brother Gerard remembers ing back to Denewood one day and discovering a very large American making himself a cup of tea. Of course Pat had not told Gerard that â€˜Soupyâ€™ Campbell would be staying for a few days â€“ a bit of a shock. As a commentator and administrator Pat gave  per cent to this new venture. His famous commentary during lives games in the Andersonstown Leisure Centre is still talked about.On the sporting front, Pat finally finished up as a member of Falls Bowling Club where he spent many happy years as a player, administrator and advisor to the long suffering groundsman. Pat eventually became the club president, something of which he was particular proud of. He also became president of the private greens â€“ a role which again Pat embraced with diligence and total commitment. A spokesperson for Falls Bowling Club described Pat, their th President, as someone with a personality that â€œcould fill the Waterfront Hallâ€. â€œHis passing has left a gap that we will not attempt to fill.â€Married to Shelia since August  , Pat lived le to the full, had a hugely positive influence on many and ultimately made a dference. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

title: history man joes lifetime in community
story: HAVING been involved in community development for the best part of three decades, Joe Baker is a familiar face to many in North Belfast, but he is probably most recognised as one of the cityâ€™s leading resident historians.Joe has been involved with the Ashton Community Trust virtually since its inception in the early-s and now sits on its board. It was also during that time that he became involved in the Belfast History Project.Throughout his career, Joe has written, and published, books, magazines and newspaper articles for a range of media outlets during his career but, unlike some historians, his expertise grew outside the confines of traditional academia.By his own admission, he didnâ€™t do too well at school, often â€œforgettingâ€ to get off the bus at the gate. However, after ing to education at the Belfast College of Business Studies in the late s, he enrolled in history classes, which he would go on to utilise with the fledgling Belfast History Project.â€œI came back from college and started to get people involved in learning about the history of the area,â€ he explained.â€œFrom that, we discussed a number of dferent ideas. One idea we had worked on before that was cleaning up Clton Street Cemetery â€“ which was where we used to drink our cider. It was all overgrown and wrecked at the time, but we all got together to fix it up. We tied in with people like Enterprise Ulster, and then Belfast City Council took it over and a number of volunteers came on board. Through that we developed this interest in local history.â€œOnce the ball started rolling that was it. We started doing dferent educational projects. One of the things we started to discuss was putting a magazine together, which sounds very easy, but at that time there was this new thing coming out called a computer that you had to learn to use. Then you had to learn the computer programmes, which in those days was Pagemaker. Then you had to learn about printing and all the rest of it. Once we go up and running everything just fell into place.â€The Belfast History Project has been exemplary in its endeavours, setting up groundbreaking publications and establishing history tours in long-unexplored areas of the city.â€œOne of the good things is that when you look in Belfast city centre now and you see all the tours done here and there â€“ blue badge this, white badge that â€“ we get to look at it and say we did it first,â€ said Joe with a smile.â€œWe did a walking tour in the Half Bap area and one of the very first tours was cancelled because of a bomb scare â€“ not many tour operators can claim that.â€The end of the conflict has ushered in a new age of competition as ious operators compete to sell tours of the ever-developing city of Belfast. While Joe believes the growing interest in local history is â€œbrilliantâ€ he insists branding and profits have often got in the way of fact.â€œPeople are trying to put these brands on things,â€ he said.â€œAt my last count Belfast has nine-quarters. When I was at school,I was asked how many quarters there were andI had said nine I know what wouldâ€™ve happened.â€œThere is a lot of  stuff like this Tribeca development, which is a lot of nonsense.â€œThey should do the names to reflect the history of the area. It annoys me when people try to put a  history on an area or say things that just arenâ€™t true. Weâ€™ve always argued thatyouâ€™re going to do history you should tell the truth. I love to see the tourism industry grow and change, but as long as they stick to a principle of truth.â€Having started as a small local initiative, the Belfast History Project has flourished over the years, and now provides tours all over Europe, with their Russian tours booked up for nearly two years in advance. However, with all of its wider triumphs, the Belfast History Project remains a social enterprise, whose key aim is to give back to the community. Local tours and events still run regularly, such as the highly successful historical photographic exhibiton, which recently appeared in the New Lodge â€“ and, as Joe explained, â€œItâ€™s all about educationâ€.â€œIf we get people into history we can get them into education and guide them along their own path,â€ he said.â€œFor example, we had a group of kids studying the history of the New Lodge, which grew to Belfast, Ireland and then Europe. They might be kids at the time, and theyâ€™ll mess about, but about tenyears later theyâ€™ll come back to us and say â€˜That was the best project I was ever part ofâ€™ and that gives us a buzz.â€Joe continued: â€œI remember years ago that the Barrack area in the New Lodge was just called the Barrack, but younger people didnâ€™t know why it was called that. If you ask them now theyâ€™ll tell you itâ€™s because there used to be an army barracks there.â€œWhenever you do a photographic exhibition and people are learning about their own area, then thatâ€™s the start of an educational journey.â€œAs we always say, there is no more fruitful form of education than to raise the interest of people in their own surroundings.â€œOnce you do that it can open up countless other opportunities.â€

title: priceless 1916 artefacts to go on show at opening of new james
story: AN ORIGINAL  Proclamation along with the printing blocks used to create the document are among the historically invaluable artacts to go on display for the first time ever together when Ãras UÃ­ Chonghaile opens its doors next month. The Gaeltacht Quarter-based Â£. million three-storey building is set to welcome tourists and visitors from Saturday, April  when the centre opens to offer an interactive exhibition, study area, a fascinating library of Connollyâ€™s writings, cafÃ© and conference facility. The opening of Ãras UÃ­ Chonghaile comes three years after a statue of James Connolly was unveiled outside the Falls Community Council to commemorate the th year of the Easter Rising. The bronze statue was unveiled by a great-grandson of the  hero, James Connolly Heron, who described West Belfast as Connollyâ€™s â€œspiritual homeâ€.The ambitious project, led by FÃ¡ilte Feirste Thiar, will host a pageant parade on April , Good Friday, and will leave from Conway Mill, a site where James Connolly organised mill workers during the time he made West Belfast his home. â€œAras UÃ­ Chonghaile is designed to celebrate everything James Connolly contributed to Belfast, Ireland and beyond,â€ explained FÃ¡ilte Feirste Director Harry Connolly. â€œThere are five core elements to the centre, starting with the ground floor, world-class visitor exhibition. The first floor of the centre will house the Connolly Library and will consist of the worldâ€™s finest collection of writings including books we have secured from when James Connolly spent his time in Kilmainham Gaol. The fourth element of the centre will be an event and conference space, with all the first class facilities you would expect.â€Harry told the Andersonstown News that a year-long events programme has also been planned with folk sessions, film club meetings held once a month in conjunction with Sean Murrayâ€™s Respect film company, and a series of seminars and lectures.â€œWe are also delighted to announce that Hatch CafÃ© will take up residence in the centre as our hospitality partners and will be open to the public,â€ he said. Ãras UÃ­ Chonghaile centre manger SÃ©anna Walsh spoke of how the centre will host a programme of events that will try to emphasise that â€œItâ€™s not just about Connolly the Irish rebel, itâ€™s as much about Connolly the trade unionist, the guy who organised the mill workers in Conway Street, the guy who went to the States and organised several trade unions there, who all take their lineage right back that far.â€ SÃ©anna continued: â€œThere will be a major educational element to the centre, we want schools, colleges, universities coming to see the project.â€œItâ€™s ground-breaking the things we will have on display for the first time: an original Proclamation and also a half Proclamation which was actually produced by the British to use in evidence during the court martial.â€œHaving the seven signatories at the bottom was all they needed, those along with the original printing blocks will be displayed for the first time ever together. â€œAt the end of the day, the centre has to be Connolly in the round. Not the one-dimensional Connolly â€“ the Irish rebel. Itâ€™s important to the legacy of the man this centre is seen as a resource by the trade unions right across the island.â€Harry said that there is no doubt Ãras UÃ­ Chonghaile will become a key part of the cityâ€™s tourism trail. â€œWe want to thank our funders Belfast City Council and the wide range of sponsoring trade unions from the States that have pledged and delivered key financial resources which haveallowed the centre to become a reality.â€

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandBelfast International Airport lounge ranked joint third worst in the UK data-dfpadtargetingPeople were forced to queue out in the cold at Belfast International Airport due to the long security queues.By Mark EdwardsMarch   CommentsBelfast International Airport lounge ranked joint third worst in the UKBelfastThe passenger lounge at Belfast International Airport has been named the joint third worst out of  pay-as-you-go facilities in the UK. https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland belfast-international-airport-lounge-ranked-joint-third-worst-in-the-uk-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece abc AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailThe passenger lounge at Belfast International Airport has been named the joint third worst out of  pay-as-you-go facilities in the UK..pushInspectors from Which , the brand name used by the Consumers Association, ranked the Causeway Lounge at the Belfast International poorly because of its lack of shower facilities, made-to-order dishes, sparkling wine or champagne, spa facilities and fast-track premium security.Passengers pay Â£. to use the lounge at the airport.The airport has also received sustained criticism over security delays. The airport is to increase the number of security lanes from six to eight by Easter.Belfast International Airport has been approached for comment on the ranking of its lounge.A Which  Inspector was less than impressed with what the airports lounge had to offer."We were particularly looking forward to the sumptuous buffet, imagining all sorts of treats that might be available," the Inspector said. "What we found was that the buffets â€˜hot selectionâ€™ was just a single soup: sweet potato and butternut that was bland. This was accompanied by a pair of poor quality wraps. Sparkling wine and champagne wasnt included and there was a drinks limit. "The wi was the standard free wi for the airport, rather than a dedicated or faster service for lounge guests."The experience was not all bad for the Inspector."Staff were friendly and the lounge was spacious and a welcome break from a very hectic airport but very expensive for what you actually get," the Inpsector said. "Iâ€™d expect the fee to contribute to a much higher quality of food. You could get the same at Pret for a quarter of the price."Belfast International was ranked jointly with London Lutons Aspire- which offered "congealed eggs" and "stale bread rolls" and London Heathrow Terminal  Aspire.Read MorePassengers voice frustration at security delays as  miss their flights at Belfast InternationalLondon Southend Airports Skyle lounge had no hot food, no runway view and no sparkling wine, earning the facility just one star out of five.Reviews described the lounge as having "stained carpets" which were "dusted with crumbs", while the food offering was a "sad-looking buffet" of "unripe bananas" and "pastries cut into halves".Access to the lounge costs nearly Â£ when booked in advance or Â£ for those paying on the day.The airports website claims the lounge is "smart and sophisticated", urging passengers to "start your journey in real style".Edinburghs Aspire lounge received the second worst score with just one-and-a-half stars.Although the facility did include a hot food menu, an inspector described a salad as having "a past-its-best tang" while a pasta dish "looked like cat food".Complimentary sparkling wines and a la carte dishes helped London Heathrow Terminal  No  lounge share first place.It was described by inspectors as the best-equipped facility, boasting a cinema, free showers, private sleep pods and hot food options made to order.Also sharing the top spot were the Manchester Terminal   and London Heathrow Terminal  The House lounges.Which  Travel editor Rory Boland said: "Battling through security queues and the maze that has become duty-free can be such an ordeal - its no wonder that the promise of an oasis of calm in a pay-to-enter lounge is so appealing."But with lounges charging up to Â£ for what might amount to little more than a seat on a stained sofa and a soggy pastry, passengers might be better off saving their cash to treat themselves once they reach their destination."Which  reviewed  pay-as-you-go lounges at nine UK airports between September and December .

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandPlans unveiled to relax Northern Irelands drinking laws ahead of Open data-dfpadtargetingPlans have been unveiled to relax Northern Irelands drinking lawsMarch   CommentsPlans unveiled to relax Northern Irelands drinking laws ahead of OpenBelfastA government department has launched a public consultation on relaxing Northern Irelands drinking laws ahead of this summers Open Championship. https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland plans-unveiled-to-relax-northern-irelands-drinking-laws-ahead-of-open-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece bc AUTOCROP h pints.JPGEmailA government department has launched a public consultation on relaxing Northern Irelands drinking laws ahead of this summers Open Championship..pushThe Department for Communitieshas announced plans to designate certain occasions as special events which would allow them to sell alcohol outside the normal licensing hours. The  Open Championship is set to take place at Royal Portrush Golf Club from July - and DfC believe the new proposals "will contribute to the success of the event and improve the prospects of this event and others coming to Northern Ireland in the near future".The department said the plan "would benefit the hospitality and tourism sectors in Northern Ireland". Read MoreSport minister Jeremy Wright in Portrush to see Open preparationsWhole island will see idends of Open in Portrush, says ClarkeIts an Open invitation to Trump as Foster asks President to pay visit - but what could he do Northern Irelands hospitality sector has long campaigned for more relaxed licensing laws in the region, which are more limited than the rest of the UK. Any event given the special dispensation would have the power to y permitted hours for the sale of alcoholic drinks at the event. It would also have the power to permit the sale of alcoholic drinks for consumption off the premises at special events.Â  The plan includes food and drink shows where exhibitors wish to sell their products to visitors.However, the department says the the number of special events is "expected to be very small" and conditions would be imposed where necessary.UUP MLA Robbie Butler said it was a "sham" that it took the Open to force Northern Ireland into reforming its licensing laws.â€œOver the last  years there were many failed attempts at reforming Northern Irelandâ€™s outdated and obsolete liquor licensing laws," he said. data-dfpadtargetingRobbie Butlerâ€œReforms are essential, not only to update existing legislation and reflect the needs of a modern market and the increasing popularity of micro-breweries, but also to ensure that we are doing everything possible to tackle the high levels of alcohol addiction across Northern Ireland. â€œItâ€™s a sham however that it took the imminent th Open at Royal Portrush, and the inevitable embarrassment that would have been felt on an international stage, to force Northern Irelandâ€™s hand on this."DfC acknowledged that organisers of events in Northern Ireland feel that restrictions on selling alcohol "have a negative impact" on their events."The Department believes that it is important to recognise the signicant contribution the hospitality industry makes to the local economy, and assist it where possible," a department spokesperson said."It is also important that the public is protected from alcohol related harm and the Department welcomes views on the conditions that should be attached to any change in permitted hours."The consultation period will run from March  to May . Email responses can be submitted to social.policy@communities-ni.gov.uk

Today, the Belfastpublishes its annual performance guide for every post-secondary school in which pupils undertake A-levels.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland revealed-alevel-league-table-for-northern-ireland-catholic-schools-dominate-top-positions-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece b AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailJust one non-Catholic school has secured a top  place in Northern Irelands A-level league table this year. have got to be nurturedProud principals say success is because teachers, pupils and parents are unitedÂ The top-performing grammar school was St Louis Grammar School in Ballymena, a voluntary Catholic grammar where .% of pupils achieved three or more top grades.The best-performing non-grammar was St Brigids College in Londonderry, which came third overall with .% of pupils clinching three or more top grades.The co-educational Catholic maintained secondary school, where nearly % of pupils are entitled to free school meals, made a major leap up the table compared with last year, when it ranked joint rd.Principal of St Louis Grammar Sean Rafferty, whose school also topped last years league table, said he was "delighted".St Louis Grammar Schoolâ€™s principal Sean Rafferty"Its down to the hard The results relate to the   academic year and include the core GCSE subjects, English and maths.GCSE school league table - check out the full list hereThe five schools in joint first place are Loreto Grammar School in Omagh, Lumen Christi College in Londonderry, Dalriada School in Ballymoney, Rainey Endowed School in Magherafelt and Friends School Lisburn.In joint sixth place are Our Lady and St Patricks College Belfast, Wallace High School, Lisburn, and St Dominics High School Belfast.In joint ninth place are St Louis Grammar School, Ballymena, and Dominican College, Belfast.In th place is Assumption Grammar School, Ballynahinch.Four of the top  schools are all-girl grammars, while the rest are co-educational grammars.Grammar schools claimed the top  places in the league table.The top-performing non-grammar school was Castlederg High School, which ranked th in this years table with .% of pupils achieving five or more top GCSE grades. I think it reflects well on the school, the pupils and the standards set by staff."Mr Skelton said the league table "shows the success of the grammar school system" and he added: "Pastoral care is a massive part of it. Leaders of political parties opposed to military rule urged a high turnout as the only way to derail Mr Prayuthâ€™s plans." width"" "" rel"nofollow"  Thailandâ€™s Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha casts his vote Mr Prayuth was among the first to vote in Bangkok, the capital, arriving in a black Mercedes after polling booths opened at am.â€œI hope everyone helps each other by going to vote today as itâ€™s everyoneâ€™s right,â€ he told reporters after voting. He played golf later in the morning before heading to an army base to await results.The election is the latest chapter in a nearly two-decade struggle between conservative forces including the military and the political machine of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, a tycoon who upended tradition-bound Thailandâ€™s politics with a populist political revolution.Mr Thaksin was ousted in a  military coup and now lives in exile abroad to avoid a prison term, but parties allied with him have won every election since . His sister, Yingluck Shinawatra, who led the government that was ousted in , also fled the country after what supporters said was a politically motivated corruption prosecution.After the coup, political party gatherings were banned and pro-democracy activists and other dissenters were regularly arrested, interrogated and imprisoned. Just days before Sundayâ€™s election, the Thaksin-allied Pheu Thai party said the houses of party officials and its campaign canvassers in some provinces were searched by military personnel in an act of intimidation.The partyâ€™s leader, Sudarat Keyuraphan, said after voting in Bangkokâ€™s Ladprao district that she was confident of winning." width"" "" rel"nofollow"  Leader of Pheu Thai Party Sudarat Keyuraphan â€œI donâ€™t say itâ€™ll be a landslide. I donâ€™t know. Depends on the people. But I think we can win this election,â€ she said.Thailandâ€™s powerful King Maha Vajiralongkorn issued a statement on the eve of the election that said the role of leaders is to stop â€œbad peopleâ€ from gaining power and causing chaos. It was also broadcast on Thai television stations minutes before voting started.Invoking a speech by his father, the previous Thai king who died in  after reigning for seven decades, King Vajiralongkorn said not all citizens can be transformed into good people so leaders must be given support in ruling to create a peaceful nation.He urged government officials, soldiers and civil servants to look after national security.It was the monarchâ€™s second notable intervention in politics recently. Last month, he demanded his sister Princess Ubolratana Mahidol withdraw as a prime ministerial candidate for a small Thaksin-allied party within  hours of her announcement.

title: green light 100m investment new
story: The largest private residential investment in the North West is set to be approved by Derry City and Strabane District Council planning committee next week.The Â£m investment by South Bank Square Ltd proposes a  home neighbourhood development at Ballyoan adjacent to Crescent Link and Clooney Road. The outline planning application, which has been recommended for approval by council planning officers, comprises a mix of new homes including detached, semi-detached, townhouses, and apartments. Approval is expected to be granted by councillors at a special meeting of the planning committee on Monday th March. According to the developer, this new development will create and sustain employment for  full time jobs each year, during the  years it is expected to take to complete the project. If approved, a detailed application for the first phase of new homes is ready to be submitted shortly to allow construction to commence. The owner of South Bank Square, Seamus Gillan explained: â€œWe are delighted to have received a recommendation for approval from the City planners. "This is a unique site and a signicant development for the Derry City region that will deliver much needed quality family homes in a neighbourhood environment. We very much welcome the support we have received from the Council, local community, elected representatives and the signicant progress that has been made to bring forward our development plans to this stageâ€googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshâ€œIf our application is approved we will take forward proposals for phase one of the development immediately, and we would hope to secure detailed permission in order to commence development on site later this year. In addition to the new homes, our masterplan includes some commercial space, signicant play and recreation areas, a linear park and public amenity space. "Throughout the process we have enjoyed very constructive and positive feedback from the council planners, statutory consultees, elected representatives and local residents. We very much welcome this support and we look forward to this new development being our first major investment in the City.â€It is understood that,approved, this new development will also see signicant improvements made to the Caw Roundabout and Gransha junctions, conditioned to be delivered throughout the duration of the project.Mr Gillan continued: â€œFrom our early consultations with the local community, the planners and local elected representatives we have known the importance of creating a master plan for a comprehensive and sustainable development at Ballyoan. We are very excited by this development and we are delighted to be creating a beautul place to live, and contributing a new neighbourhood to the City that can also improve the lives of existing residents.â€Brian Kelly, director of Turley, lead planner for South Bank Square Ltd, highlighted an increasing demand for quality homes, and welcomed the recommendation to approve the application: â€œIn recent years there have been few developments with the ability to develop housing of this scale and investment, andapproved this will be a welcome boost for the North West economy and for home-buyers seeking quality family homes in the city.â€ â€œWe are grateful for the effort from council planners and statutory agencies to bring this application to this point, and the support that it has received from local elected representatives.â€Photo shows Seamus Gillen, of South Bank, with the plans for the new development.
